projects.title: Using large screen displays to support understanding program code
description: Trying to understand a large, unknown computer codebase is a challenging task. Currently, developers use Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) to navigate through a codebase whilst trying to connect different parts of the system together. Another approach would be to use people's spatial abilities to help with this process, but most computer screens are not large enough to display several code files simultaneously. This project will develop a huge screen viewer/editor that allows programmers to visualise multiple program files at the same time. It will use the large wall display in the centre for e-research to visualise the code.
outcomes: User study of how developers read code on large screens
Development of a web-based system to display multiple code files on a huge-screen system
Evaluation and analysis of the impact of using the system on code comprehension

projects.title: Tangible-based Programming Environment for Robots
description: Children are often fascinated with robots and want to control (program) them. Currently, most programming environments are screen-based, requiring the use of either a mouse and keyboard or a touch screen. This project will investigate the use of physical coding blocks (tangibles) as an alternative approach to programming robots. The project will involve developing the programming environment and evaluating it with children.
outcomes: Refinement of a web and tangible block-based programming system
Evaluation of the system with school-aged children

projects.title: Real-Time Face Recognition System using Modular Miniaturized Computer and Deep Neural Network
description: This research project aims at building a stand-alone hardware system that runs deep neural network learning models for real-time face recognition applications. It will use an upgraded Raspberry Pi system augmented with a GPU processing unit.

In this project, the students will create a system that can instantly know whether a person captured by the developed system camera has ever been seen before. When the system captures a face, it records the time and date so it can tell when the person has been seen previously. There are two parts in this project; a hardware part and an algorithmic part. In the hardware part, we will be using a miniaturized computer available in the market. In the algorithmic part, a deep neural network will be developed to recognize faces. The face of a captured person image has to be tracked and extracted from the background beforehand, then the recognition process starts. Python programming language will be used within Anaconda or Colab environment. Tensor flow framework and Keras rich neural network library will be used to ease the implementation of the algorithms. OpenCV library can be used in implementing the face recognition component of this project. The students are expected to code some algorithms from scratch as well as using any available library.

Applicants must discuss the project with the supervisor before submitting their preference. The allocation of the project may be declined if not discussed beforehand with the supervisor. Keen and hardworking students are encouraged to apply for this challenging yet very interesting project. Broad experiences will be gained from this project in many modern technologies.
outcomes: A system that can recognize faces in real-time
projects.prerequisites: Hardworking and keen students. Python programming skill is advantegeous.

projects.title: Automated Building Generation
description: Traditional approaches to procedural generation of buildings focus on buildings that look correct, but tend to ignore aspects such as compliance with building codes. This results in the creation of buildings that are suitable for entertainment purposes (such as in video games), but not for more serious purposes (such as health and safety training).

This project's goal is to create a procedural content generation system that incorporates building code rules (such as those related to fire control or evacuation routes) to produce output that is realistic and suitable for simulation and training purposes.

Stage one will require students to investigate generative systems and look at some building regulations, to determine an appropriate scope. Stage two will require students to create a generator that incorporates this information to produce appropriate 3D models of buildings.

projects.title: Realistic Voice Cloning with Deep Neural Networks
description: A relatively new technology, called 'Voice Cloning' is thriving with many applications demanding it. The monotonic robotic voice in virtual assistant applications will be replaced with natural human voices. Human voice cloning can make proliferated applications such as video clips, audiobooks, chat-bots, automated tutoring, etc., more engaging and dynamic. One can personalize any voice in any delivered talks. This technique can also be used to bring back the voice of a beloved family member who lost their voice due to certain chronic sicknesses in their vocal tract. Voice cloning is not a simple standard text to speech synthesis, but it is a more profound approach to replicating the targeted voices by embedding the cloned speaker's attributes. Deep neural network learning will be used in achieving this objective. Interested applicants are encouraged to read the following papers to assess the complexity of the project and whether they are interested in working on it or not.
1. "Neural Voice Cloning with a Few Samples", which can be downloaded from https://arxiv.org/pdf/1802.06006.pdf .
2. Transfer Learning from Speaker Verification to Multispeaker Text-To-Speech Synthesis, which can be downloaded from https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.04558

Applicants must discuss the project with the supervisor before submitting their preference. The allocation of the project may be declined if not discussed beforehand with the supervisor. Keen and hardworking students are encouraged to apply for this challenging yet very interesting project. Broad experiences will be gained from this project in many modern technologies.
outcomes: A software to clone targeting speakers
projects.prerequisites: good background with programming and software system setup

projects.title: Telescope scheduling
description: Telescopes observe celestial objects (or sources) in the sky. The telescopes are usually movable and can point at different positions in the sky. Very large scientific telescopes in astronomical observatories are highly specialised, very expensive and scarce. Hence, they must be used as efficiently as possible. In a typical operation mode, a telescope will be configured to observe a given list of sources, which correspond to positions in the sky. It remains pointed at a source of the list for a certain observation period, e.g. 10 minutes, after which the telescope is rotated and tilted to point to the next object on the list. Due to the fact that the movement between positions takes time and that necessary observation periods might vary, this observation of sources becomes a difficult optimisation problem. In this project you will develop scheduling and ordering algorithms to optimise the use of telescopes. This includes the development of a tool that can process lists of source to be observed which then creates optimised observation sequences that can be used for the operation of real telescopes.This project will be done in collaboration with A/Prof Willem van Straten, Institute for Radio Astronomy and Space Research, AUT.
outcomes: Telescope scheduling tool

projects.title: Avoiding communication in parallel programs
description: When the tasks of a program are executed on a parallel computer, it can be beneficial to executed the same task on more than one processor. This happens when this replicated execution of the tasks helps to avoid the costly transfer of data across the memory or network system. Scheduling algorithms with task duplication are not only allocating and ordering the tasks of a program onto a parallel computer, but they are also decided which tasks are beneficial to duplicate. In this project you will investigate different scheduling algorithms that use task duplication, varying the system model and the complexity. The algorithms will then be implemented and measured in an experimental study.
outcomes: The outcome will be an algorithm library to be integrated into existing research work of the Parallel and Reconfigurable Computing Lab.

projects.title: How much slack is in a multiprocessor schedule?
description: Parallel computing has become extremely important in today's IT world. Almost all computers are now parallel systems. To efficiently use them one needs to divide a program into tasks and to schedule them onto the processors or cores of the system. Theoretically this is addressed by task scheduling where a program is described by a directed acyclic graph, a so called task graph. The primary objective of task scheduling is the fast execution of a program, but the energy consumption becomes more and more important too. So called slack reclamation algorithms slow down the execution of non-crucial tasks so that idle times (the slack) are filled and the energy consumption is reduced. But recently the question was raised how much slack is actually present in schedules produced by modern scheduling algorithms. This project will investigate this important question, whose answer can have a strong consequence on the design of future scheduling algorithms.
outcomes: Scheduling algorithms and tools.

projects.title: Multi-Agent System Control for Smart Grid Connected Multi Energy Storage System
description: Agent- based computing has the potential to improve the theory and practice of modelling, designing and implementing complex system. In recent years, the penetration of the renewable energy sources (RES) including photovoltaic (PV) and wind energy have increased due to their environmentally friendly advantages. In a large-scale RES, the proper communication system with the smart grid is crucial to achieve stable synchronous operation throughout the system. In this project, the multiple microgrids with multiple energy storage systems will be controlled and coordinated on multi agent platform. The Arduino is used as digital signal processor (DSP) of each agent (ie. PV, Battery, etc) and transmit / receive the data packets wirelessly through the ZigBee using IEEE 802.15.4 communication protocol standard. The testbed at Power Systems Lab at Dept of ECSE, UoA would be used to experimentally validate the concept, and extend it further.
outcomes: · Research on the integration of multi photovoltaic and multi energy storage system.
· Research suitable coordinated energy management algorithms on multi agent-based platform.
· Model the suitable algorithm on the simulation environment (MATLAB/Simulink).
· Validate the proposed method in the hardware using Arduino and ZigBee.
projects.prerequisites: Students must consult the supervisor before bidding on the project.

projects.title: Robotic Yield estimation of Apple Orchards
description: This project will form a part of the multi-institution MaaraTech project being run by the CARES team at UoA - https://cares.blogs.auckland.ac.nz/research/robots-in-agriculture/human-assist/.

The students will process RGBD data collected from Apple Orchard's via a UR5 robotic arm and seek to generate a detailed 3D map of the trees and a count of the number of fruitless on them. This project will involve developing the deep learning-based computer vision models to detect the fruitless and other canopy features, and developing methods for 3D reconstruction of the point cloud data.

The research aim will be to extend the computer vision models to handle the RGBD data, and determine how to associate partially occluded fruitlets across the scan data to assemble an accurate count for the tree as a whole.
This project will primarily be done using Python and/or C++ within a Robotic Operating System (ROS) framework.
outcomes: The outcome of this project will be a yield estimation pipeline that will be able to:
Detect fruitlets and other features within RGBD data Reconstruct RGBD data into accurate models of an apple tree Provide an accurate estimate of the number of fruitlets within the apple tree

projects.title: Study the behavior of ultrasonic acoustic power transmission
description: There are several wireless power transmission methods, such as inductive power transfer and capacitive power transfer. In this research, we would like to study wireless acoustic power transfer. Students will design a circuit to generate a narrow beam ultrasound signal and then emit it through certain mediums such as air or water using piezoelectric transducers and finally detecting the signal power at a receiving side. Parametric array loudspeaker (PAL) unique acoustic feature is our means to achieve that. PAL can exploit the non-linear characteristics of air to the emitted ultrasonic beam to produce a narrow directional beam. PAL is constructed from a big array of small ultrasound piezoelectric transducers. PAL speakers are available in our labs. The power efficiency will be calculated, and a feasibility study of using acoustic power transfer will be concluded.
outcomes: A design and implementation of ultrasound transmission and receiving system
projects.prerequisites: Prospective students are expected to be motivated enough to handle the challenge. The students must see the supervisor before bidding for the project. Signal Processing course ELELCTENG 733 is an advantage to undertake this project.

projects.title: Developing an audio sensory device that allows blind people to “see”
description: People with heavily impaired vision have always relied on white canes or guide dogs to assist their navigation in their daily life. Over the past decade, research efforts have discovered that the human mind can be trained to 'visualize' objects using sound alone. For example, if one hears a burst of sound of a specific pitch, loudness, and position (achieved through surround sound), the receiver can be trained to visualize a dot, line, shape, or pattern in their mind.

In this way, experiments proved that visually impaired people could navigate set courses without white canes or service dogs. Moreover, they could carry out simple tasks which required pinpointing and grasping objects without performing sweeping motions with their hands. However, current technologies do not allow users to perceive depth in their ‘peripheral vision’, nor walk at speeds that a white cane would enable them to.

Thus, there is great potential to improve the technology of audio-sensory assistance by giving visually impaired users the ability to perceive depth. Through this, it is possible that they could perform daily tasks such as walking and grasping at speeds akin those who do not have visual impairment.
outcomes: Researching how different sounds lead to different images being visualised by a human.
Exploring how machine vision can be used to identify certain objects that visually impaired people need to exercise caution around.
Determining an appropriate optical sensor that enables the signal processing algorithm to express ‘depth’ from 2D real-time images.
Developing an audio signal processing algorithm that describes real-time images as sounds.
Investigating how surround sound can enable users to have an accurate ‘peripheral vision’ of up to 170 degrees (or more).
Measuring the speed and accuracy of a user’s response to everyday tasks, as opposed to using traditional assistive devices such as a white cane
projects.prerequisites: This is a cross-departmental project initiated by Mechatronics, by the student Urim Chae (ucha862). He will be partnering with Bill Yang (byan982). Please add Urim's name into the Team Section below.

projects.title: Deep learning the geometry of the inverse problem of electrocardiography
description: The inverse problem of electrocardiography involves predicting the electrical potentials on the heart surface from body surface recordings (ECGs). The inverse problem is very challenging, but also highly impactful. Correctly solving the inverse problem will lead to novel non-invasive techniques for localising (finding) erroneous carcdiac circuits.

We have developed a very novel technique for predicting heart surface potentials from body surface potentials for a given patient heart anatomy. Our technique involves decomposing heart and body surfaces into 3D Gaussian bases and then learning relationships via neural networks.

In this project we would like to enhance our neural network architecture with anatomical and geometric relationships to be able to predict heart surface potentials with varying patient heart geometry.
outcomes: A machine learning/deep AI technique (software) able to predict the heart surface potentials for different patient anatomies.

projects.title: Real-time embedded gastric pacemaker
description: Stomach and intestines fullfil an important life sustaining function. Stomach has an instrinsic frequency of beats (around 20 sec period) just like the heart, which allows food digestion. People suffer from slow down of the stomach's pacing frequency termed brady-gastria. Brady-gastria can lead to serious health issues like gastroparesis, highly reduced life-style and even death.

We have developed novel gastric pace making algorithms and related software implementation of these algorithms see, https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/9175500 and https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0010482519304299?via%3Dihub
The project aims to implement the developed algorithm on embedded platforms, enhance the algorithm to make them real-time, and then potentially test them with real animal experiments.
outcomes: An embedded implementation of the gastric pacemaking algorithms.

projects.title: Sing to search
description: Many a times music listeners know certain tunes (or part of a song), but do not recall the name of the song or the artist.
This project aims to allow users to hum or sing certain tunes (or part of a song) to allow searching music catalogs in their library or online.
outcomes: A machine learning architecture to allow searching songs via humming/singing.

projects.title: Optimisation of magnetic material placement in IPT pads for EV charging
description: Inductive power transfer (IPT) for electric vehicles has shown promise in recent years as an alternative to conductive charging. One of the current issues for IPT systems for EV charging is the cost of magnetic material within the system. The material costs of the IPT systems need to be reduced to improve economic viability. This project aims to create an optimisation software that optimises the placement of magnetic materials within an IPT system to lower the cost while maintaining the power transfer capability of the system.
outcomes: A generalised optimisation approach using a genetic algorithm to minimise the material usage while maximising the power transfer capability of the IPT system.
The ideal optimisation approach will utilise parallel computing to improve the time taken for the optimisation process to converge on the solution.
A prototype of the solution to verify the simulation findings.
projects.prerequisites: Both students should be enrolled in Electeng 734 (Power electronics).

projects.title: Fundamental study of power loss on the coupling plates of Capacitive Power Transfer systems
description: Capacitive power transfer (CPT) is an emerging wireless transfer technology that has drawn attention by both academia and design engineers. As a dual to inductive power transfer (IPT), a CPT system achieves wireless/contactless power transfer by electric field coupling between metal plates. A typical CPT system consists of a high-frequency DC-AC inverter, compensation networks, and two pairs of metal plates to form the required electric field coupling. Much effort has been made to improve the CPT system performance in power transfer capability, power density, etc., but how to improve the system efficiency remains a key focus of study.

This project is to establish a model for analyzing the power loss on the coupling metal plates of CPT systems under high-frequency (a few or tens of MHz) excitations. The work involves basic circuit analysis and design, high-frequency electromagnetic simulation, and laboratory measurements to determine the key factors affecting the power loss on the coupling plates.
outcomes: A verified model showing the relationship between the power loss of the metal plates and the circuit/coupling parameters.
projects.prerequisites: At least one of the prospective students needs to be enrolled in the Power Electronics course.

projects.title: Multi-Processor System on Chip for Machine Learning based Object Recognition
description: Machine learning algorithms are used in many applications from market predictions to autonomous robots and vehicles. Real time and correct object detection and tracking (such as pedestrian and vehicle detections) are critical parts of computing components in safety critical applications such as autonomous vehicles. The aim of this research is to implement a multi-processor system on FPGA (using soft-core and/or hard-core processing elements) for machine learning based object recognition.
outcomes: Investigating machine learning algorithms (deep learning) and their computational complexities for object (pedestrian and vehicle) detection.
Implementing the multi-processor system and evaluating the accuracy and system performance and discussing the design trade-offs.
projects.prerequisites: Students should have passed COMPSYS 304 and COMPSYS 305, as good knowledge of computer architecture and digital systems design is essential for this project. Students are highly recommended to take COMPSYS 701 as an elective, which can be helpful to provide additional knowledge to carry out this project.

projects.title: Reconfigurable Hardware Accelerator for Embedded Artificial Intelligence
description: Machine learning models, which are part of artificial intelligence (AI) are trained based on application-specific data and then deployed in target execution platform to perform useful predictions. Machine learning algorithms are computationally intensive so, deployment of these algorithms for embedded systems is very challenging as not only achieving the required system performance and prediction accuracy are essential, reducing energy consumption is also critical. The aim of this research is to investigate the computational complexity of machine learning algorithms, especially, deep learning algorithms for embedded applications (such as face recognition) and develop a reconfigurable hardware accelerator, which is implemented on FPGA to satisfy the required performance and accuracy while minimizing the energy consumption.
outcomes: Investigating the computational complexity of a case study for deep learning algorithm and identify the opportunities for performance and accuracy improvements using hardware accelerators. Reducing hardware complexity through algorithmic optimizations and using approximate computing will be investigated too.
FPGA implementation of the proposed hardware accelerator and evaluating the system performance and prediction accuracy for the chosen case study.
projects.prerequisites: Students should have passed COMPSYS 304 and COMPSYS 305, as good knowledge of computer architecture and digital systems design is essential for this project. Students are highly recommended to take COMPSYS 701 as an elective, which can be helpful to provide additional knowledge to carry out this project.

projects.title: Run-Time Security Threat Detection for Embedded Systems Software
description: Security vulnerabilities of network connected embedded systems, which are deployed in Internet of Things (IoT) devices have become significantly important especially in safety critical applications such as medical devices and autonomous vehicles. Due to continuous changes of security threats, employing a run-time potential security threat detection is essential. This can be considered at different components of the multi-processor systems architecture. Processing elements are the main components of such systems and identifying their security threats efficiently depends on their complexity. In this research, a softcore configurable processor based on RISC-V instruction set architecture (which is an open source instruction set architecture) is extended to support information flow tracking at run-time. The effectiveness of the proposed architecture extension and its performance overhead are evaluated.
outcomes: Investigating the information flow tracking approaches at the processor architecture and micro-architecture levels
Comparing the performance of an available RISC-V based processor implementation (on a simulation tool or on an FPGA) and compare it with an ARM Cortex A9 processor
Developing new application-specific instructions and demonstrate the performance improvements compared to the basic RISC-V processor
projects.prerequisites: Students should have passed COMPSYS 304 and COMPSYS 305, as good knowledge of computer architecture and digital systems design is essential for this project. Students are highly recommended to take COMPSYS 701 as an elective, which can be helpful to provide additional knowledge to carry out this project.

projects.title: Automated Software Test Oracles
description: Test oracle is a mechanism to determine whether an application is executed correctly. It is a reliable source of how the SUT (Software Under Test) must operate. It is also expected to provide correct results for any inputs that are specified by the software specifications, and a comparator to verify the actual behaviour. Automated test oracles are helpful in providing an adequate automated testing framework.

After test cases are executed and results of the testing are generated, it is necessary to decide whether the results are valid in order to determine the correctness of the software behaviour. To verify the behaviour of the SUT, correct results are compared with the results generated by the software. The results produced by the SUT that need to be verified are called actual outputs, and the correct results that are used to evaluate actual outputs are called expected outputs. Test oracles are used as a reliable source of how the SUT must behave and a tool to verify actual outputs correctness. Usually, the verifier makes a comparison between actual and expected outputs.

Deep Learning (DL) is an umbrella term used for a collection on advanced machine learning algorithms capable of learning complex patterns from big data. In this project we would like to explore how DL based supervised, unsupervised, or reinforcement learning algorithms can be used to facilitate the design and implementation of complex software test oracles to help reduce the difficulties and complexities of testing difficult-to-test software systems.

projects.title: Automated Intelligibility Assessments of Dysarthric Individuals
description: Dysarthria is a neurological disability that damages the control of motor speech articulators. An effective treatment plan requires a good understanding of the disability and its severity. The severity of dysarthria is usually identified by a subjective speech intelligibility assessment, which is based on the identification of how well normal speakers can comprehend the subject's speech. In this project we would like to design an Android based solution that uses Deep Learning algorithms to conduct an objective assessment of dysarthria by listening to individual's speech and conducting an automated assessment.

projects.title: Sign-language understanding using Reinforcement learning and DNN
description: This project will understand English sign-language from hand motion, gesture, and facial emotion. There are a lot of research on recognizing alphabets and numbers, but not word and sentence itself, which is more realistic and useful in real-world. Do literature survey on conventional approach, and select the best one and develop it as the first version. Then improve the method as the second version and/or integrate them to understand nuance of sign language. You may use reinforcement learning and/or Deep Neural Network (DNN). This project may be combined with other related projects, such as social human robot interaction projects and healthcare robot projects. All necessary devices will be provided.
This project includes to:
do literature survey on conventional approach find the best one for English, develop and test, and improve the method.

Project scope will be decided after the meeting with supervisors. You will bring to the role a passion for research and engineering, excellent computing skills (including a high level of programming ability), and a strong sense of responsibility. It will be better if you have an experience on vision processing and/or using DNN.

projects.title: Plant monitoring system with 3D reconstruction
description: This project will develop a system to monitor the change of plant growing. 3D reconstructed model may be needed to measure the number and size of fruit and leaves. May need to train Deep Neural Network (DNN) models to detect different fruits, such as kiwi, apple, grape, strawberry, tomato, paprica. We have a well working detection model for kiwi and apple fruits, and can easily make different models for other fruits using DNN. All necessary devices will be provided.
This project includes to:
do 3D reconstruction of plant, make different models to detect different fruit and leaves, find easy way to train models, and develop a dashboard for user.

Project scope will be decided after the meeting with supervisors. You will bring to the role a passion for research and engineering, excellent computing skills (including a high level of programming ability), and a strong sense of responsibility. It will be better if you have an experience on vision processing and/or using DNN.

projects.title: PhysiOid - A smartphone application connecting doctors and their patients
description: Immunity and other bodily systems begin to decline as one steps into his/her fifties. The healthcare industry hence requires co-operation and adherence to medical and physical activities from the elderly patient’s end. However, doctors would also need to regularly check up with their patients, process their treatments, help them exercise, and monitor their medical progress in iterations.

This research project involves developing a smartphone application that is pitched to doctors, nurses and specifically physiotherapists who can customise exercise routines for their disabled/special needs’ patients. After examining the patient’s medical condition, they can prescribe them with daily exercises that need little to no moderation, create a workout routine for them and monitor their progress in real-time. In doing so, the doctor ensures that the workout routine is followed by the patient without having to physically be present to help with the exercises.

The benefits of using the application for the patient would be that the patient gets some independence and privacy while exercising as the doctor’s visits can significantly reduce. The application is programmed to use the device sensors, to send an alert to the doctor, in case the patient is straining himself or herself or not complying to the movement restrictions of their disability.

The platform on which the application will be created would most likely be Python or C++, using features like databases to manage the patient records and progress, flexibility trackers using statistics, graphs and data modelling, and machine learning algorithms for the device sensors.

The purpose of the application is to facilitate human-computer interaction, and is targeted to be technologically simple from the GUI end. AI would be used in the application to detect patient movements by mapping their body frame and approximating their movement limits, as well as automate the patient’s progress curve, suggesting exercises specific to their disabilities based on the doctor’s previous prescriptions to patients with similar degrees of special needs.
outcomes: A functional application to help ease doctors’ duties
Get a better understanding of human-computer interaction
Estimate models using statistics obtained from patients’ progress
Create a socially sustainable model that could target audiences from different age groups

projects.title: Instantly train neural networks: One shot inverse reinforcement learning for robotic arm control
description: A key drawback of reinforcement learning is the necessity of thousands of training iterations and hand engineered training environments/reward functions. This greatly limits the flexibility and adaptability of real-world robotic systems controlled by reinforcement learning based systems.
As shown by Andrew Ng’s paper “Apprenticeship Learning via Inverse Reinforcement Learning”, there is opportunity to dramatically reduce the time and data requirement for neural network training.
Our project aims to create a pretrained inverse reinforcement system which is adaptable to novel robot arm control tasks, with only 1-3 runtime training examples provided by human teachers.
Our system could be revolutionary in the healthcare, manufacturing, and primary industries, as tasks can quickly be learnt from normal employees without an engineer’s expertise.

Three key requirements for instant training are one-shot object identification, current state classification and state specific action sequences. By separating tasks usually performed in an amorphous blob, we can leverage tremendous amounts of pretraining. Additionally, our system becomes explainable and easily manually tweaked.

One shot object identification of never seen before objects, even in different poses, angles, and lighting conditions, can be achieved through a pretrained CNN + Intel real sense depth camera. Rather than object classification, each will output heuristics such as colour, texture and patterns plus height, width, and shape respectively.

Classification of the current state will be controlled by a pretrained, iteratively optimized hand-crafted algorithm. Heuristics such as ‘robot arm distance to object’ and ‘robot arm movement’ will segment training examples into separate states. Eg: ‘State 1: move arm to object A’, ‘State 2: pick up object A’

State specific actions will be controlled by tiny inverse reinforcement neural networks. They can be tiny as they have very few inputs/outputs and are only responsible for actions in their very specific state. Their tiny size allows for very quick training.
outcomes: • Research current apprenticeship learning and inverse reinforcement learning methodologies
• Research one shot object classification via CNN and ensemble networks
• Research and experiment with neural network based robot arm control
• Develop one shot object classifier through CNN + Depth inputs
• Develop an iteratively optimised state classification algorithm based on heuristics provided by one shot object classifier
• Implement tiny apprenticeship based inverse reinforcement neural networks
• Integrate separate aspects of our system to work with a robotic arm
• Test our system for a range of never trained upon tasks
• Evaluate the accuracy, reliability and flexibility for different task types and complexities.
• Investigate future enhancements which could further improve functionality

projects.title: Robot Soccer System
description: This project will develop a robot soccer system that autonomously do soccer game. We have a famous robot soccer game, Mirosot, which is the game for the NZ Robot Soccer Championship. In this project, we develop a new game that uses three smaller and lighter robots with 3D printing in the smaller field. Example codes and all necessary devices will be provided.
This project includes to:
design a scale of the game, develop a robot body and circuit board, develop a vision and strategy SW, and do an interesting game.

Project scope will be decided after the meeting with supervisors. You will bring to the role a passion for research and engineering, excellent computing skills (including a high level of programming ability), and a strong sense of responsibility.

projects.title: Safe autonomy using synchronous AI and the F1/10 racing car
description: Cyber-physical systems, such as autonomous vehicles, use interactive machine learning modules for decision making. Current approaches use a set of interacting neural networks, called neural network ensembles, to design such systems. These ensembles are realised using multithreading-based composition, which is not ideal for safety-critical systems. Hence, for safety-critical systems such as autonomous vehicles, there is a need for rigorous approaches.

This project seeks to develop an alternative approach by reusing neural network ensembles, which are designed in the Keras library. After the application has been developed and the networks are trained, a compiler (recently developed by us), will be used to generate automatic C code, where the neural networks will operate synchronously. Our approach, thus, brings model driven engineering to the AI space. This will facilitate automatic static analysis to determine the worst case timing behaviour of the application, which is important for autonomy.

The students will develop NN ensembles for autonomous vehicle application in Keras using deep neural networks. These will be then used to design an automated platooning system using the F1/10 racing vehicles (see: (1) http://www.madhurbehl.com/f110.html (2) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vgEyvazwrU8).

The prior work on this at UPenn (Ivanov et al. below), the car only supports uniform motion. Hence, it can only deal with static obstacles. Also, they only a single car is validated. We will develop an approach for a platoon of cars following each other and will support both static and dynamic obstacles.
References

Roop PS, Pearce H, Monadjem K. Synchronous neural networks for cyber-physical systems. In2018 16th ACM/IEEE International Conference on Formal Methods and Models for System Design (MEMOCODE) 2018 Oct 15 (pp. 1-10). IEEE.

Allen N, Raje Y, Ro JW, Roop P. A compositional approach for real-time machine learning. InProceedings of the 17th ACM-IEEE International Conference on Formal Methods and Models for System Design 2019 Oct 9 (pp. 1-5).
Yang X, Roop PS, Pearce H, Woo JR, A COMPOSITIONAL APPROACH USING KERAS FOR NEURAL NETWORKS IN REAL-TIME SYSTEMS, Design Automation and Test in Europe (DATE), March 2020, Grenoble, France.
R. Ivanov, J. Weimer, R. Alur, G.J. Pappas, and I. Lee. Case Study: Verifying the Safety of an Autonomous Racing Car with a Neural Network Controller, arXiv, 2019.

R. Ivanov, J. Weimer, R. Alur, G.J. Pappas, and I. Lee. Verisig: Verifying safety properties of hybrid systems with neural network controllers, 22nd ACM International Conference on Hybrid Systems: Computation and Control, 2019.
Keras https://keras.io/
outcomes: Design and verification of safe neural networks for autonomous platooning systems Design of a autonomous vehicle platoon using the F1/10 racing cars

projects.title: Robust Sensor and App design for Biofeedback
description: Stress related depressive disorders affect the sympathetic tone, which is strongly correlated to low heart rate variability (HRV). In these conditions the heart rate goes up and the variability is minimal. There is mounting clinical evidence to this support the link between the lack of HRV and the stress related disorders [1-4].

Biofeedback is a recently studied technique to maximise heart rate variability (HRV). Slow and rhythmic breathing rate of approximately 6 breaths a minute has been shown to achieve maximum HRV. This project seeks to develop a continuous feedback loop for patients to monitor the breathing rate and heart rate through appropriate sensors and give visual feedback using an App to patients. While some recent commercial sensors are available for combined heart and beating rate, these are very expensive. We propose a much simpler sensor for this and will compare this to the commercially available Zypher device. Students will learn about new sensor design and also software design for biofeedback. This project is suited to both computer systems and software engineering students. This project will be co-supervised by Dr. Giresh Kanji, who is a clinician with extensive experience in HRV.

This project will be a continuation of the 2020 version of the project. Here, a PPG and Temperature sensors along with Arduino was used to design a system, which can obtain the heart rate and the breathing rate accurately when the subject is resting. An App was also designed that used to provide the necessary visual feedback to facilitate maximal HRV through resonant breathing. We also have ethics approval for trial of this sensor on human subjects, which will be carried out in the 2020 project.

There are several limitations of the 2020 implementation. First one is related to the fact that the sensor works only when the subject is not moving. We need to develop robust techniques to develop the sensor when the subject is moving by removing the motion artefacts. Also, the Arduino board can be eliminated so that the mobile device performs the necessary signal processing.
References
1. Farina et al. “Heart rate and heart rate variability modification in chronic insomnia.” Patients Behavioral Sleep Medicine, 12 (2014): 290–306).

2. Andre Pittig et al. “Heart rate and heart rate variability in panic, social anxiety, obsessive–compulsive, and generalized anxiety disorders at baseline and in response to relaxation and hyperventilation.” International Journal of Psychophysiology 87, 1 (2013): 19-27.
3. Robert Carney et al. “Depression, heart rate variability, and acute myocardial infarction.” Circulation 104 (2001): 2024-2028.

4. Marcus Agelink et al. “Relationship between major depression and heart rate variability. Clinical consequences and implications for antidepressive treatment.” Psychiatry Research 113, 1–2 (2002): 139–49.
outcomes: A robust technique to design a biofeedback loop using a sensor and a mobile phone App
The App provides real-time visual feedback to the user to enhance HRV
To study the imact of this on stress reduction in human subjects

projects.title: Interactivity with hand tracking VR
description: This project will explore the latest technologies in virtual reality (VR) headsets. HTC and Oculus now include built-in hand tracking on some of their headsets (so there is no need for external devices such as the Leap Motion). They also provide developer APIs that will allow programmers to incorporate hand tracking into VR apps that they develop. For this project, you will be working alongside an exciting VR company that provides unique VR experiences for its users. As part of this project, you will be exploring the hand tracking API to develop cool VR app(s) that will demonstrate novel interactivity without requiring hand controllers. The educational value of the app will be of particular interest (i.e. in helping users learn something).
outcomes: Development of VR app(s) demonstrating novel value of hand tracking.
Evaluation and analysis on the impact of the app(s) and the value added from the hand tracking.
projects.prerequisites: Passion for VR technologies Passion for developing educational applications Strong object-oriented programming skills (bonus if have some C# experience)

projects.title: Investigation of non-blocking network (Benes Network) for the optimization of CNN
description: A non-blocking network is a network that can connect N inputs to N outputs in any combination. The most familiar use of switches of this type is in a telephone exchange. The term "non-blocking" means that if it is not defective, it can always make the connection. We would like to always have a minimal network. The term "minimal" means that it has the fewest possible components, and therefore the minimal expense.

The hardware implementation of CNN accelerator is very complicated. The dedicated processor is not flexible. The more general processors are not very fast because of the delay of data transfer between memory and processor. Good use of a non-blocking network can solve the problem.
outcomes: To study the Benes Network comprehensively
To implement software to generate network configuration for different CNN layers

projects.title: Investigation of non-blocking network (Banyan Network) for the optimization of CNN
description: A non-blocking network is a network that can connect N inputs to N outputs in any combination. The most familiar use of switches of this type is in a telephone exchange. The term "non-blocking" means that if it is not defective, it can always make the connection. We would like to always have a minimal network. The term "minimal" means that it has the fewest possible components, and therefore the minimal expense.

The hardware implementation of CNN accelerator is very complicated. The dedicated processor is not flexible. The more general processors are not very fast because of the delay of data transfer between memory and processor. Good use of a non-blocking network can solve the problem.
outcomes: To study the Banyan Network comprehensively
To implement software to generate network configuration for different CNN layers

projects.title: Where do they go? Predicting individual travel activities for contact tracing and emergency rescue
description: What it is?

The proliferation of big data in transportation, for instance Smart Card (e.g. AT Hop Card) data in public transport, has provided a tremendous opportunity for transport operators to support the eradication of COVID, through contact tracing, and through search and rescue during civil emergencies. Transport operators such as the Auckland Transport may use the Smart Card data to anticipate the current and future location of each individual passenger in their public transport system, given the consent from individual Smart Card users to access and use the data.

We plan to build a prediction model that can track and predict pubic transport passengers using deep learning data-sequence modelling algorithms. This task requires a significant amount of data pre-processing and transformation, and then experimental studies to build the initial prediction model. This pilot study will enable us to utilise the transformed data and model to prepare and apply for external funding applications seeking support to build the entire data-streaming and prediction system.
Why it is new?

Smart Card data has been used to explore individual travel activities in a large scale (Kieu et al. 2014, 2018), but the topic of modelling and predicting individual travel activities in public transport has been underdeveloped. The majority of existing studies in transport demand modelling, especially in public transport, has focused on an aggregated prediction of the demand, e.g. the number of people travelling from station A to station B, rather than individual locations. Predicting individual activities in real-time is challenging, due to the complexity and correlation in sequential travel activities data. A novel data processing and modelling pipeline and framework will need to be developed to process Smart Card data into prediction of individual location in real-time.
Skills Needed:
1. Programming
2. Data analytics
3. Familiarity with Machine Learnign and Deep Learning is desired. If not familair, you'll be guided to learn

projects.title: Development of a Hybrid Transformer (HT)
description: To meet the energy demand in an efficient and sustainable manner, more and more renewable energy sources, such as solar, are integrated into electricity distribution networks. However with more penetration of renewable energy, voltage regulation of transformers by conventional means has become difficult and ineffective. This project aims to develop a hybrid transformer, comprising a conventional transformer and an integrated power electronic converter, to overcome this problem. Students of this project are expected to carry-out a thorough investigation into voltage regulation issues, and design and build a scaled down version of a HT to demonstrate its applicability. The project involves modelling, analysis, simulations and both software and hardware design.
outcomes: A prototype system
projects.prerequisites: Design 203/310/311 and ELECTENG 734 (power electronics)

projects.title: A wireless charger for underwater applications
description: Autonomous underwater vehicles, AUVs, are currently used in a wide range of marine applications such as offshore energy and marine research sectors. To power on-board equipment, as well as the drive of AUVs, batteries are used. This limits the range and capability of current AUV systems. Re-charging of these AUVs by wired means in an offshore marine environment has a number of disadvantages. This project aims to further develop a bi-directional wireless charging system that has been designed for this application. Students, assigned to this project, are expected to improve last year’s design and build a small scale bidirectional wireless charging system. The project involves modelling, analysis, simulations and both software and hardware design.
outcomes: A prototype system
projects.prerequisites: ELECTENG 209/310/734

projects.title: A Solar-powered Garden Lighting System
description: Solar powered applications that range from high power renewable energy networks to low power sensor systems are on the rise. This projects aims to develop a smart solar powered garden lighting system with remote control. Students are expected to design this system to power multiple LEDs using an energy storage. The system must have a controller with maximum power tracking and individual brightness, colour and time control through a remote link. Students, assigned to this project, have the freedom to incorporate any other smart features and must build a prototype. The project involves modelling, analysis, simulations, both software and hardware design and testing.
outcomes: A prototype system
projects.prerequisites: ELECTENG 209/309/310

projects.title: Authentic Behaviour in VR Forests
description: Virtual Reality (VR) is a useful tool for placing people in environments where it might normally be impractical for them to be (e.g. dangerous, inaccessible, or cost-prohibitive environments). One application of this is to conduct research on how people act and think within a particular environment, such as a forest containing endangered flora and fauna, without the associated ecological risks of taking large numbers of people into the real world environment.

However, if conducting research on how people act and think in a VR environment, it is important that their actions and thoughts accurately represent those that would occur in the real environment. This raises concerns about the effort needed to produce a sufficiently realistic environment (a particular concern with highly complex environments such as forests).

This project will have students develop algorithms for generating natural environments for use in VR and techniques for assessing how people act within them. The objective is to determine information such as the degree of realism or diversity of assets required to immerse subjects within the environment to the degree that they act in the virtual environment in a similar way to how they would act in a real one.

projects.title: Wearable Intelligence: A Virtual Personal Type 2 Diabetes Rehabilitation System
description: The rising popularity of fitness wearables has produced a plethora of data relating to users' exercising and biometrics. Despite the popularity, common wearable devices on the market focused only on passive data collection and lack of intelligent analytics towards the user information, which is one of the key factors preventing the long-term adoption of such wearables for many users. Users will be much more engaged with their own health using smart wearable devices if these devices can provide a personalised system to monitor themselves. Previous studies suggested supervised exercise training involving more vigorous exercise may be the most effective means to reduce hyperglycemia in type 2 diabetes. There is a potential to apply High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) for type 2 diabetes rehabilitation.

This project aims to develop a HIIT based rehabilitation system that fully utilizes the data collected by the wearables and apply data analytics into the AI expert domain for type 2 diabetes patients. AI techniques design a customized HIIT exercise plan and provide accurate rehabilitation exercise feedback to patients. The proposed system will be connected to the hospital system for doctors to monitor patients’ behaviours and provide accurate diagnosis on their rehabilitation. This study has the potential to help clinicians and researchers to have insights into type 2 diabetes rehabilitation and chronic disease management, so as to improve the healthcare professionals. In addition, this system could be extended to other domains such as elder care monitoring, virtual personal training etc.
outcomes: Research Components:
1) Research and understand drawbacks of current exercise applications that use wearable devices to develop a better application experience.
2) Investigate AI/Machine Learning techniques that can utilise research in exercise physiology to provide exercise plans, and training advice for type 2 diabetes rehabilitation.
Implementation:
Develop a mobile and Internet based software application that realises the proposed solution.

projects.title: Investigation of PCB coils for medium to high power solutions
description: Electric vehicles (EVs) are becoming increasingly popular global manufacturers look towards EVs as a method to reduce emissions. Wireless charging is a method of improving the safety and convenience of charging these vehicles. Traditional solutions have large air gaps, and uses litz wire to construct the pads.

This project will investigate the potential of PCB coils instead of litz wires. PCB coils have the advantage of being robust, cheaper than litz, and are easily manufactured. Students will use ANSYS, ICEPAK, and LTSpice (or PLECs) to investigate the electrical and thermal performance of these PCB coils and compare them with existing solutions in the wireless charging space. This knowledge will be leveraged to build a medium to high power wireless charging system.
outcomes: At the end of this project students will be confident in using ANSYS Maxwell and Icepak to get accurate electrical and thermal simulations. A new PCB coil pad will be built to validate these simulations.
projects.prerequisites: Ideally one student will have taken ELECTENG734

projects.title: Gesture set development for an AR/VR environment for building site consenting
description: Developing a gesture set for a particular scenario requires a deep understanding of how people preform a particular job and what their needs and requirements are. We are looking to support the consenting officers who check a building site to ensure that what is constructed matches the requirements specified by the council when the building was consented. This will require visualising and manipulating a 3D building model matching what is being constructed on site and checking that required conditions are being adhered to. The project will have a strong Human-Computer Interaction component to it to create a usable gesture set based on requirements of specialist consenting officers and then to test the usability of the developed gesture set. A previous Part IV project developed a gesture set to navigate a 3D building environment which may be used as a starting point for the project.
outcomes: A gesture set that can be recognised in an AR/VR environment (e.g., through a LeapMotion controller afixed to an Oculus headset) with a Unity-based software system to allow gestures to be mapped to consenting functionality.
projects.prerequisites: SOFTENG 350 must have been taken by at least one student in the group.

projects.title: Multi-user VR-based disaster preparedness environment
description: The project will create a multi-user VR environment for earthquake disaster preparedness. Current VR-based training environments allow a single participant to be trained in disaster preparedness. However, for realistic training you would want to train with other members of your class or office, as well as with NPC (non-player characters) who would create particular scenarios to respond to. We have an existing earthquake training system developed in Unity and experienced with an Oculus VR headset. We wish to extend this system to allow for many participants to be present within the same training environment and to be able to interact with each other as they progress through their training session. There will be a significant Human-Computer Interaction component to the project to design the possible interactions between participants and to test the usability of the designed solution with a class of students.
outcomes: A Unity game environment for multi-user disaster preparedness training.
projects.prerequisites: SOFTENG 350 or equivalent for at least one of the students in the project

projects.title: Supporting choice of good identifiers
description: Every developer knows that good quality code has meaningful identifiers. However it can be difficult to decide how meaningful an identifier is, and this judgement can be subjective. Ideally there would be some form of measurement that tells us how good an identifier is, but the subjective nature of evaluating meaningfulness makes this difficult.Nevertheless there are heuristics and proposals for forms of measurements that are referred to when discussing what makes an identifier meaningful.The goal of this project is to explore means to provide support to developers to improve their choice of identifier. The project is fairly open-ended. There are several directions that it could take. Evaluating how good an identifier is will require the use of Information Retrieval (IR) and Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques. One direction would be to explore which of these techniques work the best. There are online facilities to help determine information about words, such as WordNet (https://wordnet.princeton.edu). WordNet has an API allowing for programmatic access (http://www.lexicadb.com/lxserver/wn_http.html). Another direction might be to explore such facilities.Another direction might be to, rather than just provide some kind of score of goodness for a particular choice, to instead suggest alternatives. Such a recommender system could be based on existing code (of which there is a huge amount available for data mining).There are also different contexts that could be considered. It could be that the goal is to support developers to reduce the time the spend choosing identifiers, as there are reports that some spend quite a lot of time doing so. Another goal could be to provide automated feedback to students, and so helping them to learn to choose better identifiers.
outcomes: Tool that supports choice of identifiers, or study that evaluates proposals for choosing good identifeirs.
projects.prerequisites: Completed SOFTENG306

projects.title: Visualising Building Management System (BMS) data in a 3D building model
description: The buildings we inhabit have sophisticated Building Management Systems (BMS) collecting data about the performance of the building and its various systems. Currently this is only visible and available to the facility managers of the buildings. This project looks to open this data to all building occupants by allowing it to be visualised in the context of a 3D model of the building (actually a BIM - Building Information Model). An example of commercial work in this area is at this link: http://www.autodeskresearch.com/projects/dasher
outcomes: A range of visualisations of BMS data (e.g., temperatures, CO2 levels, airflow temperatures, etc) within the context of a 3D model of a building.
projects.prerequisites: SOFTENG 350 or equivalent for at least one of the students in the project

projects.title: Code Hygiene Monitor
description: Robert C. Martin identifies a number of ways to make code "clean" [Mar09]. This project will conduct a study of existing Java code to determine to what degree such code is clean. For example, Martin recommends not leaving commented code in the code base. How often does this happen? Martin also makes recommendations of the size of methods, the number of parameters to a method, and the size of classes. How often are these recommendations ignored?The project will develop a tool or set of tools for analysing code and producing reports evaluating the "hygiene" of the code. The code to be analysed will be written in Java and be from the Qualitas Corpus (http://www.qualitascorpus.com). This has more than 100 different systems and overall several million lines of code. [Mar09] Robert C. Martin. Clean Code: A handbook of agile software craftmasship. Prentice Hall. 2009.
outcomes: Tool for analysing hygiene of code
projects.prerequisites: Completed SOFTENG306

projects.title: VR simulation of war and conflict scenarios
description: How can students gain an accurate impression of war and conflict zones during their courses? Working with academics and students from Conflict and Terrorism Studies in the Faculty of Arts we wish to explore the development of a VR environment to present a realistic simulation of conflict situations. The Arts students worked on the development of scenarios that could be implemented in a VR environment. The scenario we will investigate is around hospitals including the impact of the bombing of a red-cross hospital; the impact of a cholera outbreak; etc. The system will be developed using the Unity game engine.
outcomes: A VR environment which provides a compelling simulation of conflict scenarios utilising research into, and testing of, approaches to generate such impressions.
projects.prerequisites: SOFTENG 350 or equivalent for at least one of the students in the project

projects.title: Accurate Automated Measurement Facility for Wireless Charging
description: As power levels increase for electric vehicle charging it becomes more difficult to perform high power tests accurately and safely. Due to this reason, a motorized movement rig, which can be controlled externally withdata capture and analysis is required so that users do not need to be exposed to fields in operation or connect mutiple currents and voltage probes after each movement.

This project is to build on an existing automated test rig begun in 2020 for testing IPT systems suitable for EV charging and to enhance the data collection system for capture and display while adding power control and evauation means to the existing system. The test system aims to control the ground side system laterally to simulate parking misalignment of the electric vehicle and evalaute the impact. The ulitmate goal is a working system that performs coupling, efficiency, and leakage flux measurements remotely. The base of this system which is now automated needs to be finalised and able to be aligned, while a new vehicle side assembly will be placed above the existing system to enable manual height adjustment to simulate the variablity of vehicle distance to ground.

The vehicle rig needs modifications to comply with recommended practices so a steel sheet needs to be added to replicate the vehicle chasis together with the existing aluminium sheet, and provisions will need to be made for attaching peripheral devices such as thermal cameras, voltage, current and flux probes which will feed back into a data collection system.
outcomes: The outcome of this project is a system that can automatically move the ground assembly in an EV charging system laterally while capturing data for display. Furthermore the system will need to be able to move within 1 mm accuracy and have provisions for computer control through USB. The students will need to demonstrate that they have the ability to use the system to perform some coupling measurements once the system is complete and compare this against simulated performance (which various PhD students can provide about such systems).
Ideally, a series of power tests should also be performed at multiple positions using the rig.

projects.title: Evaluation of Heavy Duty IPT EV Charging
description: While over the past two decades considerable effort has focused on wireless Inductive power transfer (IPT) for light duty electric vehicles, consumer devices and industry applications, until recently less effort has focused on improved high power wireless charging possibilities for heavy duty electric vehicles. Of particular concern is the weight and size that such high power systems need along with thermal, voltage and current constraints. In an attempt to reduce the cost and material of such an IPT system this project aims to investigate how much this can be practically be improved by reducing the charging gap and tolerance needed, while maintaining resonance for a 50kW system, using magnetic modelling in Ansys, to evaluate thermal and electrical impacts along with the power transfer capability, against a more traditional 50kW system. A prototype of the solution can be built at 5kW scale to verify the simulation findings.
outcomes: Review of state of art wireles charging systems presently used in wireless charging heavy duty systems
Understanding of impacts of size and power transfer in IPT systems with practical constraints using magnetic simulation.
Understanding of wireless charging systems for EVs including thermal and electrical evaluations.
Understanding of how to build and measure IPT systems
projects.prerequisites: At least one student should be enrolled in Electeng734 (Power Electronics).

projects.title: Exploring Human Movement in Dynamic Virtual Spaces
description: Constraints breed creativity, and the environment can constrain and shape human motion through it. This project will investigate how freeform movement (possibly including dance) in Virtual Reality (VR) is affected by the unpredictable constraints imposed by dynamically generated virtual environments.

In this project, students will investigate techniques to procedurally generate human-scale virtual environments and examine how environmental and visual complexity affects users' movement and experiences. These environments will be used in VR, in combination with full-body motion capture tools, to examine the use of these environments as a location for creative movement (and possibly dance) and the impact the constraints imposed by the environment has on the user's creativity and enjoyment.
Students working on this project will gain an understanding of VR and related technologies, as well as experience with procedural content generation techniques and user evaluation methodologies.

projects.title: Supporting code review by inexperienced reviewers
description: Code Review is an important part of developing high quality software. However its utility depends on the knowledge and experience of the reviewer. This project will explore what kind of support for the code review process can help less experienced reviewers, including those who are not themselves developers, to provide useful code reviews. The main deliverable will be a tool that takes the code under review, and presents it in a way tailored to the level of experience of the reviewer. For example, the tool might present all of the identifiers used in the code in a way that allows their meaningfulness to be evaluated without the distraction of the surround code. Or it might show the basic details of a class to allow its cohesion to be evaluated.
outcomes: A tool and process for supporting code review
projects.prerequisites: Completed SOFTENG306

projects.title: Development of an immediate feedback assessment technique platform for collaborative learning
description: Due to the increase in class sizes in introductory courses, students are becoming more distant from both the instructors and their peers. Consequently, most learning becomes individualised, with less official opportunity for students to engage in debates, discussions, and justifications over conceptually difficult problems. Yet, these activities are what forms a crucial part of internalising disciplinary concepts. Furthermore, assessments aimed at recognising understanding over factual recall become resource intensive, requiring significant marking hours, quality control and administrative overheads. As such, there is a growing need for devising activities, and exercises, that is both scalable and facilitates autonomy while encouraging collaboration and retention of threshold concepts.

The immediate feedback assessment technique (IF-AT) is an assessment technique that is often used in a team-based learning environment to impart aspects of social constructivism in the learning process which has been shown to improve both academic and collaborative abilities. The IF-AT process involves getting the learners to (1) sit an individual readiness assurance test (usually consists of, but are not limited to, multichoice questions), (2) retake the test in teams and decide on team responses collectively, (3) receive immediate feedback permitting them to reattempt the questions (for reduced points) until the correct answers are selected/revealed. Both the individual and team marks contribute towards the final grade thereby promoting individual accountability and positive interdependence.

Traditionally, this form of assessment is usually done via scratch cards (like instant kiwi scratchies) with correct answers embedded. This is both resource intensive, limiting in question types and answer placements. Furthermore, little effort is usually spent on optimising team allocations in order to maximise the benefits of team-based learning. The purpose of this project is, therefore, to develop a platform which enables the facilitation of IF-AT electronically and investigate team allocation strategies for improved learning impacts.
The intended outcome of this project is a web-based application which
enables instructors to designate, and students to participate in, a customizable multichoice question platform for both individual and team-based readiness assurance test
create an optimal allocation of students taking into account of the individual test results
generate relevant analytics on student responses.
outcomes: An investigation into current team-based learning techniques and allocation strategies for maximising learning impacts
An investigation into existing tools available for electronic facilitation of team-based learning assessments
An analysis of algorithms to generate optimal allocations
Design and implementation of a prototype for facilitating IF-AT
User evaluation (both student and course coordinator interface)
Evaluation of effectiveness
projects.prerequisites: Experience or interest in web & database / full-stack development. Interest in developing applications for engineering education.

projects.title: TeamUp - A student team allocation tool
description: There is a growing interest in incorporating collaboration into learning and teaching activities in the Faculty of Engineering at the University of Auckland in order to prepare our students for the increasing interdisciplinary, and hence social, complexity in the challenges faced by the profession. Existing design- and project-based courses attempt to capture aspects of collaborative learning by injecting peer- or group-assessed components in their coursework, but often these are designed to expect collaboration as a part of the learning (of the disciplinary content) rather than to foster collaborative skills (e.g., perspective taking, conflict resolution, positive interdependence, etc.) as one of the outcomes. Consequently, the allocation of student teams is often made based on convenience (e.g., random assignment or self-selection) rather than strategically to elicit the practice of teaming skills, and, therefore, undermines the full educational benefits associated with group work. On the other hand, allocating students in a heterogenous, fair, and constructive way is often a costly effort with significant administrative overheads and becomes non-trivial as the number of constraints (e.g., team size, academic ability, time availability, cultural/gender diversity, etc.) increases. There is, thus, a growing need for devising a scalable and cost-effective software solution for the allocation of students into appropriate teams in order to assists with the implementation of group activities that embed “learning to collaborate” on top of the disciplinary skills.

Currently, the allocation process is completed offline by collecting information from the students through a fillable form and manually assigning students into teams according to a pre-selected set of criteria. It is hoped that by automating the process, the allocation process can be made more flexible and accommodate more of, or variations in, the constraints (e.g., hobbies, learning styles, etc.) as well as alterations to the information collected from the students.
The intended outcome of this project is a web-based application which

enables instructors to create, and students to complete, a customisable form for collecting relevant information needed for team allocation enables instructors to define and/or select allocation criteria (e.g., team size range, number of available slots, gender distribution, number of prerequisite course grades to consider, etc.) generates an optimal team allocation subject to the chosen allocation criteria.
outcomes: An Analysis of existing tools used for student team allocation or similar applications
An investigation into allocation criteria that elicit ‘learning to collaborate’
An investigation into algorithms to generate “optimal” allocations
Design and implementation of a prototype for simplifying the team allocation process
User evaluation (both student and course coordinator interface)
Evaluation of effectiveness
projects.prerequisites: Experience or interest in web & database / full-stack development. Interest in developing applications for engineering education.

projects.title: Hardware-software codesign from spiking neural networks
description: Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) are well suited for Cyber-Physical Systems (CPSs) due to their inherent capability in exhibiting timing behaviour. Hence, SNN-based approaches are being used in safety-critical CPS such as autonomous vehicles. For obvious reasons, such SNN-based controllers require formal guarantees of soundness and time predictability. Hence, there is recent interest in formally verifying the timing behaviour of SNNs. However, two key challenges remain. First, the SNN models being verified are usually not linked to the design environments used in developing SNN applications. Second, there is no unifying methodology for the timing verification of SNNs which exhibit different spiking behaviour.

This work will attempt to bridge these gaps by proposing a model-based approach for the design of SNN-based controllers in CPS. We use Nengo, a well-known development platform for spiking neuron models. Controllers developed using Nengo will be transformed into a formal model called Hybrid Automata Modelling Language (HAML). A tool for this transformation has been already developed. Also, compilers already exist in our group for hardware-software co-design from HAML descriptions, i.e. there are compilers from HAML to VHDL and C. Therefore the main tasks in this project would be:

1) Creating a case study for a small part of an autonomous car. We will follow the approach similar to what is adopted by the Ghost platform: https://driveghost.com/. We will try to implement a small subset of the feature set, especially those involving real-time control. For this, mainly car following and lane changing will be considered.
2) Using the Nego to HAML tools to generate code and perform manual hardware/software co-design given a set of constraints.
3) Performing static verification to ensure correct behaviour using the HAML to Promela code generator.
References:

P.S.Roop, H.Pearce, and K.Monadjem,“Synchronous neural networks for cyber-physical systems,” in 2018 16th ACM/IEEE International Conference on Formal Methods and Models for System Design (MEMOCODE). IEEE, 2018, pp. 1–10.
E.M.Izhikevich,“Simple model of spiking neurons”, IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks, vol. 14, no. 6, pp. 1569–1572, 2003.
https://www.nengo.ai/
N. Allen, Hybrid automata modelling language (HAML), last accessed on 09/01/2021. [Online]. Available: https://github.com/PRETgroup/modular-code-generation/ blob/master/specs/HAML.md.
N. Allen, Modular code generation (Piha), last accessed on 09/01/2021. [Online]. Available: https://github.com/PRETgroup/modular-code-generation.
outcomes: 1) Creating a case study for a small part of an autonomous car. We will follow the approach similar to what is adopted by the Ghost platform: https://driveghost.com/. We will try to implement a small subset of the feature set, especially those involving real-time control. For this, mainly car following and lane changing will be considered.
2) Using the Nego to HAML tools to generate code and perform manual hardware/software co-design given a set of constraints.
3) Performing static verification to ensure correct behaviour using the HAML to Promela code generator.

projects.title: Intelligent editor for a natural language type programming language
description: Remix is a language designed to make code read like a natural language, the following is a Remix function based on English to draw and solve a maze:
on standard (black) paper
prepare the maze grid
make the binary tree maze
mark the (start) with (blue)
mark the (finish) with (orange)
solve the maze from (start) to (finish)

In order to make Remix accessible to novice programmers it needs to have an intelligent editor. This project would consist of designing, implementing and testing an editor to maximise the ease with which readable programs can be produced in Remix. It is open to many different approaches including a frame-based editor.
outcomes: A smart editor designed for the Remix programming language.

projects.title: Live coding environment for a natural language type programming language
description: Live coding is a form of artistic presentation where code is developed in front of a live audience. Remix is a language designed to make code read like a natural language. Remix could be an ideal live coding language in that even non computer experts could understand the code as it was being written.

The project would determine the best approach to be taken in creating a live coding environment based on Remix, starting with a REPL for the language and adding features to make the live interaction with language constructs efficient and clear. There is a lot of scope for originality in this project.
outcomes: A live coding environment suitable for novice programmers.

projects.title: Adding objects and event handling to a natural language type programming language
