description: Remix is a language designed to make code read like a natural language, the following is a Remix function based on English to draw and solve a maze:
on standard (black) paper
prepare the maze grid
make the binary tree maze
mark the (start) with (blue)
mark the (finish) with (orange)
solve the maze from (start) to (finish)

This project would be to determine the best syntax to use for adding full object orientation and an event handling scheme to Remix in such a way that it still reads like a natural language. Then to implement and test the design. Associated with this is a requirement to provide meaningful error messages which would assist novices using the language to rapidly understand any problems in their code.
outcomes: An extension to the Remix programming language providing method calls on objects and an event handling system.

projects.title: A Gamified VR Training Tool for Spatial Reasoning Skills
description: Spatial skills are a significant predictor of achievement in STEM subjects (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics). Furthermore, it has been shown that improvements in spatial reasoning skills, can increase achievements in mathematics. In contrast to many other cognitive abilities, spatial skills can be trained. However, it is unclear how to make training effective and enjoyable for a wide range of users. In this research, we will develop and evaluate a VR training tool for spatial skills, which will be based on recent research in pedagogy and neuroscience. In order to make the application engaging, it will contain gamification elements.
outcomes: - Analysis of the current state-of-the art in spatial reasoning skills training and their effectiveness
- Get familiar with VR technologies and game development tools (most likely Unity 3D).
- Analysis of gamification techniques and how they can be integrated in a teaching tool.
- Developing an engaging concept for spatial skills training and implementing it using a VR interface.
- Evaluating the VR spatial skills training tool
- Applying for ethics approval for the above study
projects.prerequisites: Good self-learning abilities (get familiar with a game development tool) Interested in new technologies Creativity Proactive and able to work to deadlines (ethics deadlines, user study)

projects.title: AR/VR Embodied Spatial Training
description: Spatial skills are a significant predictor of achievement in STEM subjects (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics). Furthermore, it has been shown that improvements in spatial reasoning skills, can increase achievements in mathematics. In contrast to many other cognitive abilities, spatial skills can be trained.

In this project we will investigate how spatial reasoning skills can be trained in AR/VR by physically interacting with virtual or augmented objects, and whether training effects are improved when using physical motions (e.g. hand gestures) rather than mouse interactions. In addition, we also want to investigate the role of haptic feedback on spatial training in an AR/VR environment
outcomes: - Analysis and classification of the current state-of-the art in spatial reasoning skills training and their effectiveness – in particular with respect to the type of training / virtual vs. physical material / interactions / feedback
- Get familiar with VR technologies and 3D content development tools (most likely Unity 3D).
- Developing an engaging concept for spatial skills training and implementing it using different interaction techniques and display devices
- Evaluating the VR spatial skills training tool and the effect of different interaction techniques and display devices
- Applying for ethics approval for the above study
projects.prerequisites: Good self-learning abilities (get familiar with a game development tool) Interested in new technologies Creativity Proactive and able to work to deadlines (ethics deadlines, user study)

projects.title: Web-based VR for education
description: This project will explore the development of web-based VR experiences. The idea is to allow students new to programming (and virtual reality) to experience both programming and VR development concepts by using a development environment that is much easier than the current VR development process (which requires much more technical skills). For this project, you will be working alongside an exciting VR company that provides unique VR experiences for its users. The educational value of the app will be of particular interest (i.e. in helping users learn something).
outcomes: Development of a simple web-based VR development environment to demonstrate the value of web-based VR.
Evaluation and analysis on the effectiveness of the developed solution.
projects.prerequisites: Passion for VR technologies Passion for developing educational applications Strong web-based development skills, particularly JavaScript and using extisting APIs. Strong object-oriented programming skills.

projects.title: Deepfakes for education
description: Most Deepfakes are used in a negative manner. However, can Deepfake technology be used for good reasons? This project will explore using Deepfake technology in the creation of educational content that hopes to improve engagement and motivation for learners. Please note that this will be a challenging project, and will require strong programming skills.
outcomes: Use of Deepfake techniques to develop a range of educational videos.
Evaluation and analysis on the impact of Deepfakes on learners.
projects.prerequisites: Passion for AI/ML technologies Passion for developing educational applications Strong object-oriented programming skills.

projects.title: Supporting Tertiary Students' Mental Health with an Adjunctive Smartphone App
description: Mental health disorders such as mild to moderate depression and anxiety are highly prevalent both in New Zealand, and globally, and due to a lack of accessible treatment options they often go untreated. Tertiary students are especially overrepresented in mental health statistics and many find it particularly challenging to access treatment due to a lack of resources such as time and money. Consequently, this group stands to benefit from an easily accessible, low cost, evidence-based treatment option. In December 2020, our research team was awarded a grant to develop an adjunctive smartphone based intervention package to be used alongside Focused Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (fACT), which is a brief behavioural therapy package that uses mindfulness and acceptance techniques for the treatment of mild to moderate depression and anxiety. Developing a smartphone app to use alongside therapy may help to overcome common barriers to treatment, and in some cases improve clinical efficacy. In this honours project, you will work alongside our team to help generate early stage app designs via iterative prototyping based on feedback from fACT practitioners, prospective users, and UX experts, and you will develop an MVP functional smartphone app.

projects.title: Exploring Embodiment in Immersive XR
description: How do we engage the senses beyond the audio-visual in virtual and mixed-reality? "Dancing in/Dancing With the Digital" is an interdisciplinary project exploring the alternative sense of embodiment produced by real-time, immersive technologies. Working with partners from the Auckland Bioengineering Institute and Dance Studies department, you will have the opportunity to design and co-create immersive experiences that seek to increase creative movement potential and engage multisensory awareness in their audiences, with an aim to better understand human movement and perception in XR realms. Outputs include practical and creative VR/AR prototypes allowing for virtual sensing and moving together.

projects.title: Augmented reality for stroke rehabilitation based on socio-digital strategies and indigenous knowledge
description: We radically reconceptualise healthtech through exploring how to meld ‘addictive’ sociodigital algorithms with customized cultural content in augmented reality (AR), to motivate elders to exercise, with our exemplar being stroke rehabilitation. Keeping to an exercise plan is hard, particularly when rehabilitation exercises are, by necessity, repetitive and thereby lacking intrinsic interest. Researchers have begun to understand why social media keeps billions interested and coming back for more, through social sharing, social validation (i.e., “likes” on posts), and “infinite” user-generated- and rewarding content delivered with algorithmic precision. We imagine a future where keeping to your rehabilitation plan is deliberately as addictive as social media through harnessing the supportive and incentive power of the community.

The Māori model 'te whare tapa whā’ provides a fundamentally different starting point for healthtech innovation because it includes social, physical, mental and spiritual dimensions. We build from this starting point to investigate how to codesign interactive AR experiences that integrate all four dimensions.
outcomes: This will be the first AR rehabilitation system based on indigenous knowledge to involve communities of care through socio-digital engagement strategies and algorithmic content delivery.

projects.title: Is multitasking making us stupid? Experimental investigation into the effects of multitasking
description: Headlines assert that “multitasking makes you stupid” but no causality has been demonstrated between multitasking and cognition. If multitasking with technology is changing the very nature of how we think—particularly for the worse—it is imperative to find out so that we can address negative effects. Even before COVID-19 prompted increases in technology use, US adults spent on average 11 hours per day consuming media but as few as 11 seconds focused on any given task before switching to another. Multitasking is becoming the norm but has been correlated with poor cognitive control (i.e., fundamental executive function including switching tasks and managing working memory).
In this project you will develop and conduct an experiment to test whether multitasking worsens cognitive control.
This project will include
- developing a game theory task and the analysis
- facilitating experimental sessions with participants with a 20-channel EEG
- developing scripts for behvaioural and eeg data analysis, as well as analysis of multitasking data

projects.title: Advanced Graph Analytics for Human Brain Connectivity Framework
description: Understanding human brains, the main research focus of neuroscience, is a long-standing yet challengingscientific problem. Despite many years of scientific efforts, our understanding of the mechanismsunderlying brain function, cognition and disease is still far from sufficient. Recently, network neurosciencehas emerged as a promising discipline to represent, model, and analyze human brains. In networkneuroscience, the brain is naturally modeled as a graph with neurons/brain regions as nodes and theirconnections/interactions as edges.

This project aims at developing a framework for cutting-edge graph analytics approaches for modeling and analyzing brainnetworks. The framework will inegrate multi-model neuro-imaging data for sharing, access and processing.
outcomes: The outcome of this research will include:
-Harmonize multi-modal neuro-imaging data from different sources.
-A data-sharing repository will be set up for general purposes.
-The data will preprocess with standard techniques such as realignment, normalization, etc.

projects.title: Web-scale Graph Analysis Application
description: Graph is ubiquitous nowadays: Facebook, LinkedIn, Google represent interconnect objects (e.g., people and webpages) using graphs. These graphs are often of large scale (millions of nodes and billions of edges) and require efficient specialized algorithms to analyze even for standard tasks.

This project aims at developing an open source big graph analysis application that can be assessed through a graphical user interface, standard terminal applicaitons or a Java API. The application can be potentially used for teaching, research and industrial applications, contains a plethora of built-in tools for standard large-scale graph processing and analytical tasks.
outcomes: An open source big graph analysis application that can be assessed through a graphical user interface, standard terminal applicaitons or a Java API

projects.title: Big data analytics and machine learning on the cluster of low-cost computers and FPGA nodes
description: The amount of data generated in Internet of Things (IoT) has increased considerably and reached what we categorise the big data. If all collected data is transported to Cloud, there are practically no constraints on computation resources. However, there are two major problems of huge communication bandwidth necessary to transfer all and with low latency and the storage becomes another bottleneck. These problems caused development of layered IoT supported infrastructure that consists not only of IoT end devices and Cloud, but also two intermediate layers called Edge and Fog, which enable processing and reduction of data on the way towards Cloud and potentially intermediate storage. Looking further, Edge and Fog layers can be even sufficient to provide fast near real-time processing necessary in many applications without participation of Cloud at all. The project will specifically focus on processing at Fog level with clusters of low-cost computers (Raspberry Pie, RPi) and hardware accelerators, (FPGA) which promise fulfilment of application requirements with near real-time performance. This becomes especially important for the applications that operate on huge number of streams of data coming from IoT end devices which are merged on Edge and Fog into big data streams. Specific technologies to look at are Apache Kafka, Hadoop and Spark, with the necessary extensions to programming languages (Java, Scala) and FPGA technologies.
outcomes: Identifying requirements of typical IoT-based applications (e.g. smart city, public heath, transport) selecting a motivating example.
Developing a framework for big data analytics on the existing cluster of RPi and FPGA nodes that targets Fog layer.
Demonstrating the application of the framework on the motivating example.
projects.prerequisites: Completed Part 3 in CSE or SE.

projects.title: Dynamic Reconfigurability of Industrial Automation Processes Using New Software Paradigm
description: The project explores the extensions of existing software paradigm fused in development of control of industrial automation processes in context of Industry 4.0. As the starting point, it uses Beckhoff hardware and software platform for industrial control systems based on a network of industrial PCs and interfacing nodes connected through EtherCAT, an industrial proof networking system, and TwinCAT software framework for development of control systems. The new software paradigm uses SystemJ concurrent programming language for the development of control that supports (dynamic) reconfigurability to tackle specific scenarios such as failure of specific parts of the system and fail-safe continuation of its operation, change of production process and products, etc. The new paradigm will enable modelling the system operation before the deployment of software on the real platform with practically no changes of the developed controller model. As a testbed, prototype manufacturing system in Industrial Informatics lab will be used.
outcomes: Analysing methodology of designing industrial automation systems using traditional tools, with particular focus on Beckhoff technology
Exploring extension of traditional tools with the SystemJ paradigm of design of distributed control systems
Developing control models based and demonstrating reconfigurability of system by using software only design methods
projects.prerequisites: Completed Part 3 in given specialisations; knowledge of Java preferable.

projects.title: Developing run-time system for concurrent programming language SystemGALS for RISC-V based platform
description: A new concurrent programming language called SystemGALS developed within Embedded Systems Research Group, which can be considered an extension of C programming language, requires a run-time system (support) to be able to run on traditional computer processors. System GALS allows designing concurrent programs that follow formal Globally Asynchronous Locally Synchronous (GALS) model of computation and is specifically targeting safety-critical embedded systems In the project, we are targeting a run-time system that would run on any traditional processor, but specifically exploring a variant of RISC-V suitable for embedded and real-time systems. Run-time system (RTS) is linked to the user application code after compilation of SystemGALS program. Some aspects of connection of the compiler and RTS will be looked at, too. Investigation of extending target platform to multiple RISC-V cores and, potentially, application specific cores connected via internal Network-on-Chip can be part of the project if time allows.
outcomes: Understanding of SystemGALS programming language and its model of computation
Exploration of SystemGALS compiler and the requirements on RTS to run programs on traditional processor
Design of RTS and its implementation using C
projects.prerequisites: Good knowledge of microprocessors and programming in C for embedded systems. Preferable some knowledge of run-time systems.

projects.title: WIFIMESH - Edge-layer wireless network for monitoring Bluetooth enabled IoT devices in its range
description: Wireless devices such as smart phones and watches, vehicles and tags attached to assets have become common around us. These devices and their carriers enter, move in and exit certain spaces and crowed the space saturating it with RF signals (Bluetooth in our case). Monitoring the space, recording their presence, tracking and evaluating performance of wireless communications is the objective of this project. Creation of resilient low-cost monitoring network capable for detecting and identifying objects in its range will be first achieved by monitoring devices with certain standard wireless connectivity (Bluetooth). The monitoring network will use Wi-Fi as its primary communication standard and be able to detect devices that use Bluetooth (and Wi-Fi). The network, called WIFIMESH will be based on proprietary protocol to enable reliable transfer of information between its nodes in mesh type topology and exchange of information with the edge computer(s) placed at certain locations within the range of WIFIMESH. The data collected by the network will be transferred and to the Edge computers (in our case Raspberry Pie), where it will be analysed.
outcomes: Investigation of proprietary protocols on Wi-Fi networks
Development of a protocol for creation of WIFIMESH with resilient behaviour with respect to loss of the network nodes
Algorithms for recognition of Bluetooth devices with standard wireless network in the range of WIFIMESH
Creation of recorded datasets for big data analytics
Creation of experimental WIFIMESH in Engineering Building (start with Embedded Systems Lab)
Development of rapid deployment strategy for WIFIMESH
projects.prerequisites: Good knowledge of microprocessors, C programming, basic knowledge of communication protocols, some knowledge of real-time systems.

projects.title: Mobile air quality sensor for smart city applications
description: The internet of things technology enables distributed and mobile devices to be deployed across the entire city, offering intelligent services in our day to day lives. Air quality is one of the most important parameters to be monitored to ensure our surrounding environments are suitable for our physical activities (living, working, exercising, etc.). This project aims to design and develop a system that acquires air quality data from distributed and mobile sensors, aggregate the data periodically, and support visualisation of data as a time series for smart city monitoring application. Investigation of the pattern of city-wide air quality over time will also be conducted to demonstrate the practicality of a smart city air quality monitoring application. A reasonable knowledge of network/mobile/web programming and web-based visualisation is ideal.

projects.title: Millimeter-wave based Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM)
description: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) is a technique that is commonly applied in many domains such as robotics, UAVs, and autonomous vehicles for these mobile devices to learn and navigate around an unknown environment automatically. Depending on the sensor input (optical laser/LIDAR, ultrasonic, radio-base signal), different accuracy and performance can be achieved in SLAM. This project aims to investigate the potential of using the state-of-the-art millimeter-wave based radar as the sensor input for SLAM for applications such as intelligent indoor robot navigation.

projects.title: Gamification-based education platform for sustainable agricultural and environmental applications
description: The internet of things (IoT) technology enables distributed large-scale sensor deployment for applications such as smart city monitoring, emergency event detection, and environmental and agricultural monitoring. One of the purposes is to help to achieve more sustainable (or green) practices in our day to day actions (e.g., save water, reduce waste and carbon emission). However, there is a gap for people to understand and interpret a large amount of IoT data. This project aims to explore ways of using gamification to interpret IoT data (with expert knowledge/model) as a game to educate/train its players to achieve sustainable and green operations in applications such as the environment and agricultural monitoring.

projects.title: ReType - The Game
projects.prerequisites: good programming skills

projects.title: Software ecosystem explorer
description: Most modern software systems depend on other software components. These dependencies create networks of software projects (called software ecosystems). It is unknown how knowledge is spread across such ecosystems.

This project will develop a visualisation tool to support research on software ecosystems. The tool will visually display interconnected software projects and related software changes made across those projects. The project will employ machine learning techniques.
outcomes: A visualisation tool which displays various aspects of software ecosystems to support researchers and software practitioners.
A research study on overlapping changes on at least one open source software ecosystem using the developed tool.

projects.title: Collaborative data labelling support tool
description: When training a supervised machine learning model, labeled training data is required. This project will develop a web-based software application for multiple distributed collaborators to manually label data for machine learning tasks. The application design must consider data security and privacy to ensure users have provenance over their data. Research will be undertaken to identify best practices to ensure data provenance. Research will also be undertaken to ensure the developed software application is fit for purpose.
outcomes: Web-based software application to support collaborative data labelling tasks.

projects.title: STEAM education for Young Maori-Pacific Learners
description: STEAM toys are fast gaining popularity among young children, where children get an early exposure to technology, in the hope that it will kindle an interest towards science, technology, engineering, Art and mathematics in future. However, many of these toys are designed in a more commercial sense and tend to have less educational quality and value. Work has already been carried out to develop education-rich activities to inspire young children, aged between 8 to 12 years, in electrical engineering. These activities allow young children explore the wonders of electronics and other hardware, giving them guided and well-informed exposure into engineering.

This project the aims to extend, enhance and redesign these activities to make them appealing in a Maori-Pacific context. Research will need to be conducted into the current learning trends, interests and engagement capabilities of young Maori-Pacific learners. Based on these findings the project will set out to redevelop and adapt the activities to suit these learners. Te Reo Maori is expected to be utilized in this context, to design the educational aids, experiment instructions etc. The use of Te Reo Maori in these activities will help non-Maori Pacific learners embrace the correct terminology, allowing Te Reo Maori to be extended further into science and technology education. These activities will then be tested among children with Maori-Pacific and non-Maori Pacific heritage. The long-term goal of this project is to attract more students from the Maori-Pacific communities into STEAM fields.
outcomes: · Create an engaging platform to inspire young Maori-Pacific learners in electrical engineering and associated sciences. · Investigate learning trends, interest levels and engagement capabilities of young Maori-Pacific learners. · Identify ways to redesigns and adapt the existing STEAM activities, educational aids and experimental instructions to better suit the Maori-Pacific learners. · Adapt Te Reo Maori throughout the learning process, to make it equally appealing to both learners with and without Maori-Pacific heritage. · Test out the designed activities and gather information on each activity to reflect the success level of each activity in both learning groups. · Inspire more Maori-Pacific children to develop an interest in engineering at an early stage, through exposure and genuine interest and understanding.
projects.prerequisites: Ideally have a good understanding of Maori-Pacific culture and a reasonable command of Te Reo Maori. Students must consult the supervisor before bidding on the project.

projects.title: Supercapacitor assisted whiteware for renewable energy operation
description: Renewable energy generation is highly variable, and dependent upon the precise location, time of year and day, other environmental conditions and surrounding structures etc. Therefore, a great degree of regulation, power conversion and energy storage is required to produce a useful amount of renewable energy for household or commercial use. In the solar energy context, the power generation is in DC form, which then needs to be converted to AC power to align with the regular household mains supply. However, in most appliances the final consumer load actually requires DC power, requiring an internal AC to DC conversion stage. The DC generated solar energy needs to be converted to AC and then the opposite internally. Energy lost at each power conversion stage reduces the overall efficiency. Additionally, AC power transmission also leads to about 30% energy loss at each stage of transmission, and with declining popularity of AC load the need for AC power transmission is further reduced. By delivering most of the locally generated renewable energy to the final consumer loads, a much larger power output can be expected from such renewable sources.

A DC microgrid, allowing DC generated energy to be delivered directly to the load in the appliance, would significantly improve the overall energy efficiency allowing renewable sources to produce more output power. A supercapacitor bank and its associated long-time constant allows the renewable energy to be efficiently harnessed, stored and delivered to the load, while meeting the peak current demands of the load. This is a bottleneck in present battery based energy storage systems associated with renewable energy systems. This DC powered modern “inverter driven whiteware” such as refrigerators and heat pumps, will be powered directly via SCA converters energised by a DC bus derived from a solar or wind energy source. It will essentially mitigate the need for traditional large battery packs that are inevitably part of renewable energy generators and hence address the issues of the limited lifetime, a finite number of charge/discharge cycles and the need for responsible disposal at the end of their lifetime. Supercapacitors being a relatively new technology has a lot of potential to improve renewable energy storage.
outcomes: · Investigate the power generation variations in Photo-Voltaic (PV) systems and how supercapacitors would be able to overcome these variations to successfully power appliances directly. · Develop a supercapacitor assisted energy storage system, which can be charged directly using the highly variable PV systems. · Develop the required hardware to deliver DC power directly to the DC load of the whiteware, while accommodating some of the limiting factors of supercapacitor technology.
projects.prerequisites: Students must consult the supervisor before bidding on the project.

projects.title: Power factor and harmonics in dimmable LED lighting systems
description: Introduction of the LEDs to green building designs brought significant energy savings, as the LEDs deliver high luminous flux per watt. Moreover the LEDs can be dimmed to reduce their light output depending on the demand. This will further save energy. However a typical dimming process is frequently based on pulse width modulation technique (PWM), and introduced many harmonics as well as reduces the power factor of the luminaire. When luminaires are dimmed, the lighting system produces many harmonics (often >10%), and the power factor drop to as low as 0.6. These parameters put tremendous stress on the electrical network and the green star rating of the entire project.

In this research we will be investigating processes responsible for the power factor (and harmonics), and will propose a solution. This is an innovatory research, and there is very little of research done in this field (dimmable LEDs are relatively new products).
outcomes: Propose and test technique to supply dimmable LEDs and maintain high power factor.

projects.title: Battery pack for laptop
description: Power packs are frequently used with low power devices, for example mobile phones. In this project we will develop a power pack working with a laptop, and to supply charging current for the laptop’s batteries.
As a research project, our approach is to explore many options and possibilities. These must be evaluated and most suitable techniques must be determined.
Next prototyping is expected, followed by testing and adequate evaluation.
outcomes: Deliver a working prototype and evaluate its performance.

projects.title: Names Atlas
description: A multi media platform which will provide information about names ( including place, pronunciation, distribution over time) for the Taranaki/Westcoast region of New Zealand – which if successful could be extended to other parts of NZ, or any other global region. The project will involve the building of software-based tools that will search archival material from the Taranaki/West coast region , identify names and collate information on the commonness of the name over time, plus the geographical areas the name occurs. It also involves the maintenance of the already existing Names dictionary. Also involved is the creation of a client-server-based web app that will enable a user to input a name and be able to pull out information about the name such as pronunciation details, sources where name can be found, geographical location, and usage over time . The aim if to have this tool will be publicly available. The project will also involve ensure that the data storage solution ensures Taranaki/Westcoast maintains sovereignty over the names data.

projects.title: An Oration assessment tool based on Deep Learning
description: The ability to have competency in te reo Māori is important in many aspects of professional life in New Zealand. The University of Auckland education paper EDUCM199 requires all students to pronounce well a preset 36 word Pepeha (speech). With student numbers of over 300, the marking of the Pepeha in EDUCM199 is a time consuming process. The purpose of this project is to create a platform which will enable the markers to be able to up load all the speeches, provide a markup for each speech which indicates which words were pronounced correctely and incorrectly, and a final mark. The platform would also enable a human marker to edit the decisions made by the autotmatic system if required. The automatic marking would be based on using a combination of speech recognition and deep learning techniques. If time allows it would also be very useful to have a practise module for the students , providing them feedback when they are practising the 36 word Speech. The skills learnt in this project would be audio processing, speech recognition, deep learnining, and GUI design, and working with a motivated client. The ability to speak te reo Māori is not necessary.

projects.title: Multi-Lingual Speech Assessment using Deep learning
description: This project will investigate the use of deep learning for speech assessment, with the view to build a pronounciation assessment app for English and te reo Māori. Other languages would also be considered, but there would need to be corpora available on which to do the analysis. Feed back will be given to the user on how they are producing sounds. If the user is producing the sound incorrectly, feedback will be provided to the user on how to improve their production. The solution will involve deep learning. Machine learning has been used with great success in the field of speech recognition, so at one level sucess of the task is almost guaranteed. However this projects aims to take a more critical look at the solutions, and what is of most interest is the limitations and points of failure of the the solution. To be an effective speech assessment app, we need to know how sensitive the system is to speech errors. In addition if the application is to run on a smart device, the final solution must not take up an excessive amount of computional resources. Therefore processing power is also an important consideration for the final solution. The skills learnt in this project would be audio processing, speech recognition, deep learnining, and GUI design. The ability to speak te reo Māori is not necessary.

projects.title: A comparison between traditional signal processing and machine learning methods in  speech analysis capturing time varying information
description: Machine learning is increasing being used in speech analysis for automatic speech feature extraction. It has immense appeal as many of the machine learning platforms are much easier to use than the traditional speech processing methods. When it comes to the recognition of speech machine learning has been used with great success. However the question is can machine learning techniques be used for accurate measurement of specific speech features which vary over time? This project investigates the use of machine learning in the identification of an important speech feature, called a formant, and compares the results to traditional formant tracking methods.

projects.title: High-Performance Metasurface Waveguides
description: Waveguides for high-frequency signals have traditionally been realised using bulky three dimensional structures (e.g. coaxial cable, rectangular/circular waveguides supporting non-TEM modes, etc). However, recently there has been some interest in developing planar waveguiding structures using metasurfaces. Metasurfaces are two-dimensional equivalents of metamaterials, which are structures that contain a repeating microstructure - the elements of which are much smaller than a wavelength. Although the basic design of metasurfaces is well understood, high-performance designs (which have low loss and low dispersion) can be challenging to realise.

In 2017 a working prototype of a metasurface waveguide was sucessfully produced. This project will be extended this year to consider additional bend geometries and launching structures by (i) identifying appropriate implementation strategies; (ii) designing, modelling and optimising these structures using CST Studio Suite/Microwave Studio; and (iii) fabricating the design(s) and measuring their performance.
outcomes: Designs of metasurface waveguide bends and launchers (from coaxial cable).
projects.prerequisites: Prerequisite ELECTENG307, corequisite ELECTENG721.

projects.title: Cyber Secure and Resilient Energy Neighbourhood
description: The dependence on secure electricity supply to residential customers has been heightened during the COVID-19 pandemic globally. The decarbonization agenda also has accelerated the growth of PV generation and home storage installations. The introduction of new loads such as EVs containing built-in IoT components mean that the landscape for homes is quickly changing into a smarter, more-connected one.

In 2020, a project on Cyber seure smart homes was completed, which identified how standards that are applied to distribution substation could find its way for secure smart homes of the future. This was aimed to cyber-harden homes that could emerge as teh the weakest link of future smart grid networks and can act as a backdoor to neighbourhood networks. An OSI model was identified as a framework and a protoype attack-defend scenerio based situation was simulated. More future work was identified to be carried out in this space.
outcomes: Research Components
● Investigate communication models/architectures that can be applied to smart homes and the smart grid network
● Evaluate cyber-security challenges in neighbourhood IoT infrastructure
● Analyse cybersecurity risks pertaining to different OSI levels
● Research different cyber-physical protection measures
● Develop a use-case for demonstration purposes
projects.prerequisites: Preferably one student enrolled in ELECTENG 731 in semester 1 and ELECTENG 703 in semester 2 of 2020.

projects.title: Improved Coupler Design for High Frequency Leaky Waveguide Antennas
description: Leaky waveguide antennas are a promising type of antenna that may find application in future in-building millimetre wave communication systems. The half-mode substrate integrated waveguide (HMSIW) is an example of such an antenna, and can be used to provide a moveable point of radiation that can ameliorate the effects of shadowing in obstructed office environments. A key component of these antenna systems is the coupler, which is needed to connect ’standard’ coaxial transmission line systems to the waveguiding structure. To be effective, good coupler designs require low VSWR over a wide operating bandwidth and be of very low profile, and achieving all of these requirements simultaneously can be challenging.

This project will investigate coupler designs by (i) identifying appropriate implementation strategies; (ii) designing, modelling and optimising these structures using CST Studio Suite/Microwave Studio; and (iii) fabricating the design(s) and measuring their performance.
outcomes: Designs of leaky waveguide antenna couplers.
projects.prerequisites: Prerequisite ELECTENG307, corequisite ELECTENG721.

projects.title: CoXercise - Collaborative Exercise Games
description: COVID-19 has brought to light the importance of social interaction via online platforms in today’s environment. A large proportion of the population do not complete sufficient physical activity, but social interactions seem to provide motivation for physical activity. Although offline social games such as traditional sports are popular, as well as online exergaming such as Just Dance, there haven’t been much effort to encourage social collaboration for online games. The project proposes to design an exergame that encourages social interactions and collaboration (maybe some competition), and compare the results of offline and online modes of the game. The project hopes to shed some light into this new field of exergaming, and encourage positive collaboration amongst the comfort of the home.
outcomes: - An exergame that has both offline (single-player) and online (collaborative) modes.- Comparisons between offline exergaming vs its online collaborative version.
projects.prerequisites: SOFTENG 350

projects.title: Investigating the Effects of Diffraction for High Frequency Communication Systems Design
description: In the context of electromagnetics, diffraction is the bending of electromagnetic energy around corners and surfaces. It is a frequency dependent effect, and is known to become less significant as the frequency increases. However, it is still important to have an understanding of diffraction to allow system planners to assess whether it can be used to reliably communicate, or whether it can provide unwanted levels interference from adjacent co-channel transmitters due to inadequate shielding. Diffraction can basically be subdivided into two types - edge diffraction (which is the bending of electromagnetic energy around sharp edges, which may be curved and have arbitrary internal angles) or surface diffraction (in which the surfaces are considered smooth).

This project will investigate the effects of diffraction by (i) identifying techniques for modelling diffraction (likely based on the geometrical/uniform theories of diffraction); (ii) implementing a diffraction calculation code in MATLAB; and (iii) using this code (likely in conjunction with CST Studio Suite) to investigate a range of diffraction scenarios of relevance to high frequency communication system design.
outcomes: MATLAB code for diffraction calculations, series of experimental results quantifying effects of diffraction for a range of geometries of relevance to indoor wireless systems design.
projects.prerequisites: Prerequisite ELECTENG307, corequisite ELECTENG721.

projects.title: Peer-to-Peer Transactive Energy Platform For Neighbourhoods
description: Increasingly homes and businesses are investing in solar PV, high-energy battery storage systems and EV's. There is a need to develop mechanisms, tools and framework to purchase electricity not only from the energy retailers but also to trade peer-to-peer amongst consumers. Block chain architecture, using Ethereum hard-fork implementation of Smart Contract, was a pathway that was conceptualized, developed and trialled using transactive energy framework, through a 2017 Part IV power system project. The proof-of-concept was demonstrated, using the two UoA 3-kW grid connected solar system, battery storage, smart meter, PLC, micro-grid simulator, New Zealand wholesale real-time electricity market display etc. available at the Power systems Lab and interacting with UoA property services for grid services.A subsquent 2018 project developed a conceptual peer-to-peer that explored implementing the concept of time-value [as per the following publication Zhang, Z. J., & Nair, N.-K. (2017). Distributor “time value” pricing framework to schedule distributed energy resources. International Transactions on Electrical Energy Systems, e2374-e2374. 10.1002/etep.2374.] This project explored integration of the developed concept using commercially available home-automation products (e.g. Apple Homekit, Nest etc.) through proprietary and standard-based protocols.

A recent publication from the group identified how this concept could be expanded across a wide geographical area with visibility from a distribution utility with improved distribution management system (DMS) funcationality.

Chopra, A. R., & Nair, N. K. C. (2020). A Review of Methodical Decentralisation of Energy and Energy Transactions Utilising Distributed Ledger via Transition Architecture Based Framework. 2020 IEEE Power and Energy Conference at Illinois (PECI) Champaign, IL, USA, USA: IEEE. 10.1109/peci48348.2020.9064650
The New Zealand Government has recently called for solutions to address the following objective that aligns with the previous projects that has been described earlier.
Innovative distribution and retail solutions to manage energy from the local generation and storage, for example peer-to-peer trading to share excess energy generation with other households.
The 2021 project aims to develop a prototype with the intent to address all practical issues such that it is possible to be commercially deployed to a neighbourhood in New Zealand.
outcomes: A working prototype to be trialled and implemented across a neighbourhood.
Business-case development to assess the pricing and economics of the system.
Integrate the developed solution to Virtual Power Plant Model Research Literature
Assess the feasibility of how the neighbourhood solution could be integrated to Distribution network DERMS (Distributed Energy Resources Management System)
projects.prerequisites: Preferable to have atleast one student of the group who is enrolled into Power system specialization of courses ( ELECTENG 309, ELECTENG 731 and ELECTENG 703)

projects.title: Measuring Separation of Concerns
description: Separation of Concerns is a principle for designing software. This project will examine what research has been done on this subject, in particular proposals for assessing designs according to how well they follow the separation of concerns principle. It will evaluate any proposals found and/or new proposals developed by applying them to a collection of existing designs for a small system. Specific tasks will be:

review the literature on separation of concerns manually evaluating a number of existing designs with respect to separation of concerns to establish a ground truth apply any proposals found or developed for measuring degree of separation of concerns
outcomes: Report describing results of proposals found or developed and their evaluation.
projects.prerequisites: Completed SOFTENG306

projects.title: Inteconnection Guidelines for Grid-following and Grid-forming AC Microgrids
description: Grid-interconnection of BESS (Battery Energy Storage Systems) to MV/LV distribution network would impact the distribution network voltage profile, thermal loading, power flow, safety, and protection. Grid-interconnections standards and guidelines mandate the interconnection requirements to regulate general technical requirements, power quality requirements and safety and protection requirements. There are no interconnection standard or guideline exclusively for BESS. A 2020 part-IV project foucssed on developing some best practices of guidelines that could be followed by NZ Distribution Utilities in this space.

Recently there has been development from IEEE on Grid-following and Grid-forming Microgrid architectures in IEEE publications. The implementation is primarily based on inverter-interfaced PV, storage and other micro-generation resources. There is a need to research into developing interconnection guidelines if these microgrid architecture become operational in NZ in the coming years which is the focus of this project.
outcomes: Systematic review of Grid-Forming and Grid-following inverter-interfaced AC Microgrid
Emulation of Grid-following and Grid-forming equivalent Micro-grid networks in Power Systems Laboratory using Grid-and Battery Emulators

Identifying the emerging standards around grid-forming and grid-following inverters and testing some of the commercial inverters if they comply with expectation. (This scope will be attempted if there are no Lock-down due to COVID-19)
Potential case study for a Grid-following AC Microgrid for a New Zealand Distribution Utility.
projects.prerequisites: Preferably one student enrolled in ELECTENG 731 in semester 1 and ELECTENG 703 in semester 2 of 2020.

projects.title: Using Drone for Automated Garden Watering
description: The aim of this project is to program a small and low cost drone that is capable of identifying the plants in a garden (and storing their x,y,z coordinates), then flying over them periodically to water the plants. The navigation system of the drone will be implemented using embedded system platforms, where Inertial Measurement Units (IMU) and the GPS are used for drone stabilisation and to collect the coordinates of the plants. The required software to implement the sensors’ signal processing, drone’s navigation system algorithms and the required PCB will be developed in this project.
outcomes: · Investigating drone stabilisation algorithms to allow it autonomously to hover over specified locations.
· Investigating IMU for drone stabilisation and its possible interaction with a GPS based system.

· Considering the required level of accuracy of the system to identify individual plant, compare the GPS based accuracy with other types of relevant sensor (such as cameras) and determine the cost effective and accurate enough sensor for this application.
· Design the required PCB and implement the system software. Test the final implemented system in a suitable environment.

projects.title: Synthesizer for low dexterity users
description: Music has proven to be an effective therapy for anxiety, pain, nausea etc. However, many patients are unable to create their own music for a variety of reasons, such as low dexterity due to age or disorders (e.g. Parkinson’s). Our team would like to address this problem by creating a synthesiser which can be used by children and elderly adults alike. The proposed unit is designed using sheets and sticks of graphite which control the frequency of different individual synthesisers, by dragging the lead across the graphite. This requires significantly less dexterity than instruments such as keyboard or guitars, which typically control synthesisers. The unit will also serve as an educational aide for physically impaired students with an interest in music. The intended outcome is to have a fully functioning prototype consisting of 3 individual synthesisers (square, triangle & sawtooth), stereo output and audio effects (delay and overdrive) to create a versatile instrument. The synthesisers will be analogue while the audio effects will be added by a microcontroller (ATMega328PB Microcontroller). In addition, the volume control will also be designed using graphite to ensure maximum comfort for the user.
outcomes: • Research methods of designing synthesisers using analogue circuitry • Research the use of graphite as a variable resistor • Design a working square wave, triangle, and sawtooth synthesiser • Research methods of creating audio effects using a C-based microcontroller • Use a microcontroller to create audio effects • Creating a stereo output for the synthesiser • Testing concepts using software simulation • Building a fully functioning demo prototype

projects.title: User feedback dashboard
description: Software user feedback is often used by developers to improve their software. This feedback can come from a variety of platforms, including app stores, social media, and software forums. Software users have reported different motivations to write feedback on different platforms. This research project will include a study of software user feedback on popular platforms to examine the differences of user feedback on each platform using machine learning and natural language processing techniques. The project will also develop a dashboard to display a summary of user feedback to a software team to help them identify software improvements.
outcomes: An analysis of differences in user feedback across platforms. A web-based dashboard that summarizes user feedback.

projects.title: INVECT – INteractive Visualisations for EduCation of Thermodynamics
description: An important component of an undergraduate chemistry curriculum is Thermodynamics. Thermodynamics is the branch of physics that deals with the relationships between heat and other forms of energy. In particular, it describes how thermal energy is converted to and from other forms of energy and how it affects matter.

Thermodynamics is a difficult subject to learn due a large number of definitions, a lack of a clear distinction of different thermodynamics concepts, and a lack of suitable mental models and intuitive explanations, which easily causes misunderstandings. Also, the subject requires understanding of a wide variety of fields, reaching from atomic theory and quantum mechanics to probability and statistics. Finally, it has been claimed that the subject is hard to teach using the traditional bottom-up approach.
Visualisations have been successfully employed in education to improve understanding of complex data and relationships. Examples are molecular chemistry, anatomy, mathematics and algorithms.

In this research we will investigate the development and effectiveness of a visualization tool for teaching introductory university-level thermodynamics. We will analyse existing visualization tools in education and identify properties making them effective. We will investigate in more detail what makes thermodynamics heard to learn and based on this we will design and a evaluate a suitable visualization tool supporting learning.
Research Challenges
· Identify and categorise properties making visualisation tools effective for education.
· Identify key concepts in thermodynamics and suitable visual representations and processes to illustrate them.
· Develop mechanisms to provide feedback to students about learning progress.
· Make the tool motivational and intuitive to use so that it can be employed by students at home without instructor support.
· Investigate the effectiveness of the proposed solution.
outcomes: · The creation of a visual tool that effectively makes Thermodynamic energy transfers more comprehensible. It must:
o Be relevant to undergraduate Thermodynamics education (we will use the University of Auckland curriculum).
o Does not already exist.
o Contributes to existing thermodynamic teaching tools in a meaningful way.
o Improves understanding of the subject.
projects.prerequisites: · Basic understanding of thermodynamics · Good mathematics / statistic skills recommended · Good communication skills recommended

projects.title: Development of a High Power Cryogenic Motor Driver
description: There is a strong push to electrify transportation. However, one of the major barriers to electrifying mass transport systems is the weight of the existing electric drive systems. As a solution, light and compact electric machines that use high temperature superconducting (HTS) material have been developed and continue to improve. The electrical system that drives these superconducting machines also need to be light and compact in order to help develop electric drive systems with sufficiently high power and energy densities.

Work done to-date shows that there are some advantages to operating wide bandgap semiconductors such as Gallium Nitride (GaN) at low temperatures, as it allows reducing losses and improving power density. Therefore, this research will look into developing a prototype motor driver, composed of a cryogenic GaN inverter and corresponding motor controller, for driving an electric motor and using this setup to evaluate its suitability for transport applications.
An application with the following specifications will be considered as a case study to evaluate the suitability of a GaN based inverter for driving a HTS motor.
- DC-link voltage: 475 V
- Rated motor voltage : 325 Vrms
- Rated motor power : 10 kW
- Motor type: PMSM
outcomes: Research Components:
● Understand how Gallium Nitride (GaN) inverters operate at room and cryogenic temperatures
● Development of a prototype GaN inverter and motor controller
● Evaluate the performance of the GaN inverter at 294K (i.e., room temperature) using an
inductive load
● Evaluate the performance of the GaN inverter at 77K using an inductive load
● Evaluate the performance of the motor controller at 294K
● Evaluate the performance of the motor controller at 77K
● Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using a GaN inverter to drive a HTS motor
projects.prerequisites: ELECTENG 734

projects.title: AirBnB for Parking
description: There is a long-standing issue around finding affordable parking spots within reasonable time and distance constraints in cities. This often occurs when parking near major event venues such as Eden Park, or in the Auckland CBD and nearby suburbs, where roadside parking options are quite limited or no-parking zones are heavily enforced.

A solution to improve the availability of affordable parking in cities, is to allow the public to rent out their parking spots or driveways they are not being used. This product would be best marketed around events and in busy streets near suburbs and CBDs. This project contains many design decisions, such as pricing, discovery mechanism, and time enforcement.

Research can be done around the similarities, differences and unique value propositions of existing parking rental platforms. Additional gamification features could be added to make the app more appealing and rewarding to users. User testing will be performed to determine the adoption rate and quantitatively and qualitatively measure the usability of the system.
outcomes: Investigate similarities and differences between existing parking rental platforms
Discover reasons behind the slow adoption of rental parking business models and the drawbacks of existing solutions
A user-friendly application which implements a rental parking solution
Market appeal and business strategy to attract new users
Usability analysis on existing parking rental applications
Collect and analyse user data to improve the application design
Review system to improve the visibility of listings
Development of a prototype/MVP informed by requirement elicitation from potential customers

projects.title: Application of Machine Learning on Automated Web Data Sourcing
description: Entering the technological new age of AI and Big data, efficient and effective data sourcing have become more important than ever before. It is estimated that over 2.5 quintillion bytes of data are created every single day, and it's only going to grow from there.[1] This project aims at investigating the possibility of utilising machine learning techniques to optimize current data sourcing methods and propose an efficient and effective way to source data from the web.

With the recent release of the Generative Pre-trained Transformer 3 (GPT3)[2] and many other machine learning models, it enabled numerous new exciting applications of artificial intelligence in web development. This includes generating SQL and Latex code from the description, generating web UI components from the description and also opening the possibility of “intelligent” web crawlers.[3]

Essentially, this project aims at investigating, designing and building an automated application for building web-based data sourcing tools such as web crawlers, leveraging the newest machine learning technologies.

Potential usages of such web crawler builders or automated data sourcing tools include gathering information for university researchers, sourcing general multimedia files on specific topics and product market research for industrial companies. For example, a detailed use could be gathering price and related information of a specific product.

The proposed area of research includes researching and evaluating existing data sourcing methods, investigating and designing architectural designs of web crawlers with the integration of machine learning techniques, assess the performance, accuracy, or the validity of the proposed solution, investigate potential enhancement with new technologies in the foreseeable future.
References
[1] Web data statistic
https://www.socialmediatoday.com/news/how-much-data-is-generated-every-minute-infogra
[2] openai/gpt-3: GPT-3: Language Models are Few-Shot Learners
https://github.com/openai/gpt-3
[3] Application Demos of GPT 3
https://github.com/elyase/awesome-gpt3
Prompts, Examples, & Demo's for OpenAI's GPT-3 API
https://www.buildgpt3.com/category/data-tools/
Automating Code with Machine Intelligence | by Nathan Lambert
http://towardsdatascience.com/automating-code-with-machine-intelligence-d7aae24f851f
GPT-3: Creative Potential of NLP. New ML milestone by OpenAI — in action | by Vlad Alex
https://towardsdatascience.com/gpt-3-creative-potential-of-nlp-d5ccae16c1ab
25+ Big Data Statistics - How Big It Actually Is in 2020?
https://techjury.net/blog/big-data-statistics/
outcomes: Research and evaluate existing implementations of Machine Learning on information sourcing.
Research and evaluate architectural design patterns of web crawlers.
The main aspect of research focuses on the implementation of Machine Learning on web crawling.

projects.title: Chat bot for MInfoTech course recommender system
description: Entrants into the University's MInfoTech programme require a lot of highly personalized course advice to tailor their programme to their specific needs. Traditionally this has taken the form of a number of emails, calls and meetings between each individual student and the programme directors, which has proven to be unsustainable as the enrollment numbers increase.

Last year, a recommender system was developed which aims to ease some of this burden on the directors by partially automating course recommendations based on students interests and prior study, which they enter into the system. We now wish to extend this further by incorporating a chat bot.

The chat bot could potentially allow students to enter the information above using natural language, rather than filling out online forms. It could also be used to provide assistance if students are stuck / unsure of how to use the system.
outcomes: Research into chat bots
Selection of chat bot engine
Incorporation of engine into existing web application
Testing to gauge accuracy of chat bot responses
projects.prerequisites: Ideally an AI / machine learning / data mining / natural language processing course, but is not required. We can learn as part of this project!

projects.title: An Educational Tool to Enhance Feedback for Code Style
description: The purpose of this research is to investigate how a tool that automates feedback on code style can benefit the learning of beginner software developer students, in particular those that are new to object-oriented concepts. Clean code is heavily sought by working professionals because software products are often built and maintained by teams of developers. Therefore, code requires ease of consumption and collaboration. However, a clean code style is difficult to enact, particularly when first learning the various (and often conflicting) theoretical concepts. It is best when students are actively practicing clean coding, but they often lack direction on where they could improve on with, for example, their assignments. This stems from a lack of timely, specific, and standardized per-course feedback. Additionally, feedback for code style is only given at the end of a coding assessment, and often many weeks after the due date which renders the feedback irrelevant. Students will then unlikely go back and reiterate their assessment to improve the quality of their code. Would a student-friendly tool be useful for providing consistent feedback throughout a student’s coding assessment?

We will explore how the automation can provide feedback, where it will be defined as a grading against criterion (e.g. naming, complexity) and “big-picture” improvement hints on where they could go next (e.g. coding style violated / could have applied this design pattern). The subjectivity of code style will be addressed with available extensive configuration to create per-course standards.
outcomes: Research and develop "clean code" criterion for student assessments.
Investigate existing tools for automated code style feedback.
Develop "big-picture" hints that direct students on where to improve on their code style.
Develop a tool that automates feedback on code style, which is tailored towards students and how they learn programming.
Effectiveness of the student-friendly automated tool.
